course.subject: MATH
course.name: Honors Calculus I
course.description: This is the first in the sequence MATH 1023 â€“ MATH 1024 of honors courses in one-variable calculus, with particular emphasis on rigorous mathematical reasoning. Topics include inequalities, functions and their graphs, vectors, limit and continuity, extreme value theorem, intermediate value theorem derivatives and differentiation rules, mean value theorem, l'HÃ´pital's rule, Taylor expansion, and applications of derivatives.
course.prerequisites: Level 5 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M2
course.exclusions: AL Pure Mathematics; AL Applied Mathematics; MATH 1012, MATH 1013, MATH 1014, MATH 1020

reviews.author: fake
reviews.title: very nice
reviews.comment_content: This is the first in the sequence MATH 1023 â€“ MATH 1024 of honors courses in one-variable calculus, with particular emphasis on rigorous mathematical reasoning. Topics include inequalities, functions and their graphs, vectors, limit and continuity, extreme value theorem, intermediate value theorem derivatives and differentiation rules, mean value theorem, l'HÃ´pital's rule, Taylor expansion, and applications of derivatives.
reviews.comment_teaching: very good. FF is a humorous and nice man. He is willing to answer all kinds of questions from students.
reviews.comment_grading: very good. It's very easy to get an A range in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: only 5 questions every week.

reviews.author: knowing
reviews.title: A subjective review from a survivor
reviews.comment_content:
A good and satisfying course, for those potential math major students.
Covering:
   sequences (chapter oneï¼‰
   functions  (chapter two)
   differentiations (chapter three)
Each chapter provides relevant propositions/rules and their proofs. As expected, we learn some fundamental knowledge about these stuffs, and how to use them to deal with math problem. Especially, seems that the understanding of different axioms/rules/propositions and their relationships is the core of this course, for instance, you need to learn how Lagrange Remainder theorem is proved---its proofs bases on several propositions proved in previous lectures, with each of them pointing to some earlier propositions(sounds like a recursion tree). Anyway, it aim is building the foundation for you upcoming math studys, so what you can expect is something fundamental, which is usually related to proof-based problems.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Actually, I think it might not be appropriate for me to make any comments on professor Fong's teaching, since most of the content I've learned is self-taught. However, there is one thing I can say: his lecture note helps me a lot. Organized beautifully with interesting problems followed behind each chapter, it absolutely worth reading through. As for lectures, I think he mainly focuses on propositions and its proofs. Seldom(?) does he talk about any problems provided in HW or lecture notes, but I suppose there is no need to---solutions are provided by students  in "discussions" in Canvas. But beware---these solutions are not always correct, so read it carefully.

By the way, I LOVE LIU WENWEI. His tutorial lessons is AWSOME!!!
reviews.comment_grading:
Though called abslotely grading, he sets the grade cuts based on score distribution. It makes a curve, eventually.
Grade book shows that one-thirds students falls in the A-range.
A medium grade gives you B+.
Lower quartile this time gives you B-.
3 students fails.
I don't know whether can that be called a good grade course, but that is the typical grade distribution of a honor class.
The best conclusion I can derive is that if you spend tons of time on this 3-credit course than you probably won't get a grade lower than B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Hard to say. It depends.
Someone can derive a multivariable function where the input is taget grade and intellegent, with workload as the output. As for me, I spend a lot of time---maybe more than half of my total study time---for this math course, and received a A+ eventually. For homework, it depends on your teammates. I have two nice teammates, so we three share the work load of HW and it didn't use us a lot of time(2-4 hours each week probably). But to truely master the content it requires a lot of practice and thinking, which is extremely time consuming. Doing pastpapers and read through kenneth ross's book(elementary analysis) helps, while they also take tons of time. So get prepared for a tough journey.

reviews.author: Jio
reviews.comment_content: Class that was pre-enrolled for me, and we did have a zoom meeting to make sure that everyone have the idea  about how hard it is. And in my point of view it is hard but not too hard that you have no idea while learning. I'm quite sure the things taught in this class will absolutely be helpful for further learning .
reviews.comment_teaching: ff is a very nice prof and he would answer those questions. But I would like to say something about the ta Liu Wenwei, he was very very smart that you can hardily catch up to his steps unless you spent a lot of time before his t lessons. But the things he taught was very very useful and interesting such that I think its even better worth it to go to his class compare to those lectures if you have very limited time and you may learnt the knowledge before.
reviews.comment_grading: Actually have a very big a range but all your classmates are very smart so if you want to get an a you have to be very smart or to work very hard.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is big but not as big as your professor will tell you. In the zoom meeting we are taught that you have to spend about 2-3h a day to learn math. But it is actually not that big. I spent about 40min a day learning math and finish the weekly homework in 3-5h.

reviews.author: Momspaghetti
reviews.comment_content:
Very nice content.
Professor Fong has exceptionally good lecture notes, which have a natural flow, making the content easy to understand. Lecture notes also include very good exercises, which I strongly recommend doing. I wish all the honors math courses had similar notes (and unfortunately, they don't).

Each assignment, called a problem set, contains around five nice problems, which are very similar to exercises in the lecture notes. There were 10 assignments.

Exams, however, are much more difficult than exercises in the lecture notes, so it is recommended to solve problems from past papers of prof. Fong and prof. Ivan Ip, which are approximately the same difficulty as the exam.

Overall, the course is very well-crafted to both provide you with a good amount of knowledge and improve your problem-solving skills. My friends, who did not do many proofs in high school said that the course significantly enhanced their proof skills.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching was really good. The pace of the lectures was just right to follow the ideas, and you had time to think of proofs yourself. During the lectures, Professor Fong jokes very often, which creates a pleasant and relaxed atmosphere in the class.
Math 1023 with prof. Fong was definitely the most well-taught class I had this semester.
reviews.comment_grading: I guess grading maximizes your performance. (Check other reviews for the grading scheme)
reviews.comment_workload:
For me, the workload was light, as I did lots of proofs and gained a lot of math maturity back in high school. The whole workload for the week was around 5 hours, which involved around 1.5 hours of reading lecture notes and 2.5-4 hours of solving and writing up problems.
Despite that, my classmates who did not have that much exposure to rigorous proofs had to spend around 8 hours a week on the course.

reviews.author: Chris LI^_^
reviews.title: Very nice teaching
reviews.comment_content: Briefly, The content covers the proof of the limit and differentiation part in high school. Also, it covers some concepts like density of rational numbers, achimedean property...... which are helpful in analysis. Although you may have heard some of the proof in high school, it may not be totally rigorous and have circular reasoning, our prof would present those proof in a more natural and rigorous way in his lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof is willing to solve our questions during lesson and after lesson and his teaching is fun. You won't feel stressful and lonely even the course content is hard.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very good, you can get A if you are uq. 1023 would put the greatest emphasis on final exam, so it is no need to be too frustrated if you didnâ€™t get a nice grade in mid term.
reviews.comment_workload: The worload is queit high for me, the most time-consuming part is to do the problems in lecture notes and digest many new contents, but the difficulty of hw is still ok for me. In addition, If you haven't learn any university stuff and have just completed, I recommand you to preview them first ( you can visit prof's blog, it contains his lecture notes)

reviews.author: CHEN Ruiping
reviews.title: A rewarding and solid math course
reviews.comment_content: 3 parts: limit of sequences, limit of functions and differentiation. Well I think the first 2 parts are quite easy and the third part is a bit challenging. One thing I like about this course is that every proof in this course is logically rigorous, so in 1023 there's no such concept that you're given the conclusion but don't know how to prove. That feels good.
reviews.comment_teaching: Reading FF's lecture notes is enough. Going to the lecture can be helpful, but there's nothing beyond his notes.
reviews.comment_grading: Around 35-40% A range, requiring an overall >74, but only 7 A+'s, requiring an overall >93. Easy for A, hard for A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Not very heavy I think. 9 homework to turn in in total, with 5 problems each. Well exercises on the notes also worth trying. I've never been to the tutorials basically, and I also got an A. You can just do these exercises yourself, which are posted on Canvas.

reviews.author: Prof.Wang
reviews.title: an attractive but a little difficult course
reviews.comment_content:
this course is a good introdution to the calculus for the beginners.
It tells us what the math in university is. It is a little difficult at the beginning, for you need to learn how to express your thoughts in an mathematical way and understanding many new concepts. After the midterm, it will be quite easier, because the function part has many connection with your high school. All in all, I think the content is good. but you need to learn a little for this course in your holiday.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. FONG is a good teacher. He is very genius. He can explain the difficult knowledge in a simple way, and make it easier to understand. He can solve your question easily, since he always know where your problem is. My advice is to ask him as much as you can.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is a little heavy. You need to finish a difficult essay each week and write it in latex.

reviews.author: LunarKaze
reviews.title: Real analysis in disguise
reviews.comment_content:
If you are not 100% want to be Math major (i.e. Phy and Chem), GO TAKE MATH1013, even you get 5** in both Math and M2. It is because what you will learn in this course is totally different from what you expected and learnt in M2! You will learn theorems like MVT and completeness axiom, which partially belong to real analysis! The course teaches you logic rather than Math. So rather prepare yourself by studying pure math before taking the course, or TAKE MATH1013, where what you learn is adequate for being a Phy or a Chem Major!

WARNING: NEVER OVERESTIMATE YOUR ABILITY!
KEEP CLAM AND QUIT MATH 1023
reviews.comment_teaching: FF is a great professor that he will answer questions from students after class right out of the lecture hall. Also, his lessons are never boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is not bad.
You can adjust the weight of your marks

Homework: 0~20%
Mid: 10%~40%
Final: 40%~70%

A+: 93+
A:  80+
A-: 74+
B+:65+
B-: 55+

I am not going to reveal my grade : )
It is not bad but 100% detrimental to getting 4+ TGA.
I LOVE MATH 1023 SO MUCH (Â¬_Â¬ )
reviews.comment_workload:
9 written assignments with 0.1 bonus mark for typing latex.
To be honest, the questions were not that hard as long as you put days and nights to study it. : )

Don't underestimate the "power" of that 0.1 mark. It can save your grade.

reviews.author: DwayneJohnson
reviews.title: More like an introduction to analysis course
reviews.comment_content:
1 limit of sequences - rigorous definition
2 squeeze theorem
3 monotone sequences, Cauchy sequences
4 infinity, limit of functions
5 rigorous definition of function limits
6 rigorous definition of function limits, conâ€™t
7 continuity
8 derivatives, differentiability
9 chain rule, implicit differentiations
10 monotonicity, first derivative test
11 mean value theorem, lâ€™Hospitalâ€™s rule
12 Taylor series, higher-order Taylor approximation
13 higher derivative test, convexity and concavity
14 (Not tested) Complex numbers, Euler's formula, big idea of the proof of fundamental theorem of algebra, brief overview of analytic continuation

Challenging content, with some from analysis. The concept of supremum and infimum is tested in both exams, luckily the techniques are taught by FF thoroughly in class. I think I learnt a lot of bonus things from this course too, such as the way to reindex  and reorder a double sum--I was always scared to deal with those. I'm sure there are other extra things I learnt along the way, but it's hard to come up with it on the spot. Anyway, this course is a good place to develop your mathematical rigor. I'm not sure if this will be useful in physics, but I think this course is fun so whatever.
reviews.comment_teaching: FF went through every step extremely thoroughly, barely skipping any steps in computation problems in lecture. He prepares jokes before lecture too. He has several office hour to answer questions/ clear doubts, although I never asked him personally--I just ask TA and some PG dailos in discord--They respond quite quickly too.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very nice. Above 74 will be A-, above 80 will be A, and above 93 will be A+. A friend of mine scored like 20-30 in both exams and somehow he still passed as C+, quite nice indeed.

There is also a bonus marks scheme where you post solution to the lecture notes exercise, but the marks are trivially little. By that I mean you need to post like 30 solutions first and correctly in order to earn 1 extra mark. So just work hard in exams and don't even trust this bullshit system--it was designed for you to help your peers only.

Finally, the grade is calculated as follows. grade = max{Î» homework + Î¼ midterm + Î½ final : Î» âˆˆ [0, 0.2], Î¼ âˆˆ [0, 0.4], Î½ âˆˆ [0.4, 0.7], Î» + Î¼ + Î½ = 1} It appears this system allows you to all in final, but I do not dare to do it.
reviews.comment_workload:
Originally I wanted to give a B for the workload. Generally we are given two weeks for each homework but still is a bit chur since I understand it could be quite difficult. For me, I spend a whole day, from morning to night to finish each hw (including typing latex), and it was exhausting. Ofcourse, you can form a group of 3 with your classmates to complete each hw, but I don't recommend it because it's better to complete hw on your own so that you fully digest the content.

Ultimately I give a C for the workload, since doing homework alone will not get you a good grade. In addition, you need to complete all the lecture notes exercises, all the In-syll problems in K. Ross's book, all the tutorial questions, maybe look into a few math contest problems, spend some free time looking at calculus problems, doing HKAL past papers to develop some skills that are underdeveloped in DSE. Maybe even do ym notes (this I didn't do, I think the previous exercises are sufficient). Even so you still can't guarrantee an A+.

Most time (in your entire semester) will be spent in doing the exercises provided and any additional material as required

reviews.author: security_guard
reviews.title: Professor Fong is very good
reviews.comment_content:
I will let the other reviews cover this area. Just a standard calculus course that is almost fully rigorous. In the last lecture he ran out of stuff to teach so he sketched the proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra.

Also his exams sometimes have a really weird looking q3, telling you to do something with a function that has some seemingly arbitrary properties. That is actually taken from some research papers...
reviews.comment_teaching: I don't really listen in lecture, but from my ambient awareness, he explains things really well. Sometimes he makes arithmetic mistakes but that is normal for all maths professors.
reviews.comment_grading: Very good absolute grading. 80 guarantees an A. If you are not retarded (if you are in ust, you are not, yeah the bar is that low) and willing to work hard, e.g. do all his lecture notes exercises and find him/someone if you have questions, then you should be able to get at least 75% in midterm and final. Then if you do your homework properly, you can get over 80% and get an A.
reviews.comment_workload: For me it was around 2-3 hours per week, instead of his recommended 3-4 hours per day since I know most of the stuff already. Sometimes the homework is quite hard though. Like one time one of his homework problems is a lemma from a paper.....

reviews.author: TReEd
reviews.comment_content: Textbook written by Yan Min was fairly reliable with good content. All needed material can be found in it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Xiong follows the textbook in an ordered sequence. However, nothing was done other than reading the text book.
Professor Xiong adheres to a structured approach by following the textbook's prescribed sequence of topics. However, it is worth noting that the teaching methodology seems to be primarily centered around reading and studying the textbook without incorporating additional instructional strategies or activities. While textbook-based learning can provide a solid foundation of knowledge, it is essential to supplement it with interactive and hands-on learning experiences to foster a deeper understanding of the subject matter.

While following the textbook's sequence provides a structured framework, it is important for Professor Xiong to consider integrating supplementary teaching strategies that actively involve students and encourage them to explore and apply their mathematical knowledge in diverse ways. This will not only enhance the learning experience but also contribute to the development of well-rounded mathematical skills and a deeper grasp of the subject matter.
reviews.comment_grading: Not bad. 95/100 midterm and 89/100 final, homework around 85/100.  finally got A-. The course examination was too easy to figure out a better grading scheme.
reviews.comment_workload: Very low workload for people with interest in math. Thnk more and you can get better understanding of the course.For individuals with a keen interest in mathematics, one of the key advantages is the potential for a relatively low workload. When you delve deeper into mathematical concepts, engaging in critical thinking and reflection, you can achieve a much deeper understanding of the subject matter. By dedicating more time and effort to pondering mathematical principles and exploring their applications, you can uncover hidden connections and develop a more intuitive grasp of the course material. This increased level of engagement can lead to enhanced problem-solving skills and a greater ability to approach complex mathematical challenges with confidence. Furthermore, the pursuit of mathematics becomes not just a task to complete, but a fulfilling intellectual journey that rewards curiosity and exploration. So, by investing more mental energy and embracing a reflective mindset, individuals with a genuine passion for math can unlock a richer and more rewarding learning experience.

reviews.comment_content:

As summarized by Prof. Ip in the first lecture, this is an introductory course to Math analysis in disguise. For people without a solid math background, e.g. Math Olympiad, the gap from high school math (e.g. DSE Math Core and M2) to the rigorousness in this course is very large, so be prepared to take some time to get used to it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
----------------------------- ğ‹ğ„ğ‚ğ“ğ”ğ‘ğ„ğ’ -----------------------------

The teaching is very concise and clear, but the speed is very fast. His English accent is good enough for us to follow, and he knows Cantonese as well. You are free to ask him questions after the lecture. There is usually a 5 min break in the middle of a lecture, so your brain can take a rest.

The handwriting is done on GoodNotes with screen recording. If you cannot follow the pace, you can review the lecture by watching the video.

The course content follows mainly Yan Min's notes, but occasionally there will be extra content with supplementary notes. Besides, there will be 1 worksheet per 1-2 lessons that demonstrates some approaches to easier problems.

---------------------------- ğ“ğ”ğ“ğğ‘ğˆğ€ğ‹ğ’ ----------------------------

There is 1 tutorial per week, demonstrating some approaches to very difficult problems, a lot with long solutions that won't appear in homework or exams. However, I think more explanation can be done on how the solutions are achieved, instead of leaving us the impression that only experienced math students can come up with the solutions.

------------------- ğ…ğˆğğ€ğ‹ ğ‘ğ„ğ•ğˆğ„ğ– ğ’ğ„ğ’ğ’ğˆğğ -------------------

Before the final exam, there will be a final review session revisiting the concepts, demonstrating some problems, and going through the cheat sheet.
reviews.comment_grading:
------------------------------ ğ†ğ‘ğ€ğƒğˆğğ† ------------------------------

Take the maximum mark such that the total is 100%:

Homework 20%
Midterm 10%-40%
Final 40%-70%

This means you can save your midterm with your final, but not vice versa. Therefore, make sure you put enough effort into preparing for the final exam.

The grade is decent. A range is given to people with 60% total marks or above, though I was sadly 1.25 marks from A-. You secure a B+ if you are above the mean.

-------------------------- ğğğğ”ğ’ ğğğˆğğ“ğ’ --------------------------

The homework offers a bonus course point of 0.2 by submitting a LaTeX-generated .pdf file and the original .tex file instead of handwriting. Therefore, you can get a total of 2 total course marks (without the *20% for homework). I think it is worth the time to type LaTeX, as the 2 course marks may be saving you for a higher grade.

You can also earn a bonus course point of 0.2 by finding and reporting a typo in Yan Min's lecture notes, homework, or homework solutions, capped at 2 points. Yan Min's notes contain a decent amount of typos, especially in computation steps, but hard to find in my opinion since the notes are quite long. In contrast, I think typos are easier to be found in Ivan's homework solutions. Some easy ones are missing a "d/dx" and missing a limit symbol.

There was also 1 bonus mark given by simply asking a question for the review session.

With the highest possible bonus course points of 5, you can get one subgrade higher, so they are worth the time completely.

------------------------------- ğ„ğ—ğ€ğŒğ’ -------------------------------

The midterm and final exams are extremely difficult, you will feel like vomiting blood during the exams. The exams kick off with a very tricky question (What is the name of the mathematician in the portrait?) (What is the meaning of some weird notation?). Then, there are a few short questions, which are already quite difficult for normal people like me.

Then, they are followed by 2-3 computation questions which are where most people get points from. Each is worth around 10 points. For your reference, midterm has limit computations that require you to apply basic limit knowledge like sinx/x->1 as x->0 and Squeeze Theorem, while final has limit computations that require you to apply the Taylor series (very ugly and tedious). Do not use a calculator to estimate the limit as the value may be extremely large.

Afterward, there are 2 long problems with around 4 parts each. These are the most difficult questions that I usually don't know how to do. But by writing something, regardless of correctness, the lenient T.A.s may give at least 1 mark. You can write down the approach to a problem if you failed to work out the exact details, and you will usually get more than half of the marks.

------------------------ ğ†ğ‘ğ€ğƒğ„ ğ‘ğ„ğ‹ğ„ğ€ğ’ğ„ ------------------------

Finally, the final exam result and letter grades are quickly released within 24 hours after the final exam, so don't check your result if you think it may affect your performance in other final exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
--------------------------- ğ‡ğğŒğ„ğ–ğğ‘ğŠ ---------------------------

As a student who got 5** in DSE Math Core and 5* in M2, the workload was like an 8-credit course. But given this is an honor course, I would give the workload a D.

There were a total of 10 homework. Each homework would be released each week, containing 4 compulsory long problems and 1 optional problem with 2-4 parts each. But the deadline was usually 2 weeks later, meaning there was a week of buffer in case you cannot finish it within the first week.

The homework problems require a lot of thinking. Therefore, it's better to form groups to work on the homework, as lots of times, you wouldn't be able to come up with a solution. Usually, the solution only takes not more than 5 steps, so if your unsuccessful attempt is overly complicated, you may be in the wrong direction.

It took me around 5 days to complete one homework at the beginning of the course, and it gradually reduced to 3 days per week as I got used to the rigorousness.

However, the homework was very rewarding, not only because they were intellectually stimulating, but compared to MATH 1013 difficulty, you can have a good grasp of the concepts and computations in the topic, but it was completely not enough for handling Ivan's exams.

-------------------------- ğğğğ”ğ’ ğğğˆğğ“ğ’ --------------------------

The homework offers a bonus course point of 0.2 by submitting a LaTeX-generated .pdf file and the original .tex file instead of handwriting. This also takes a lot of time, usually within 1 day. I recommend using the online platform Overleaf - https://overleaf.com for its good editor (e.g. highlight brackets, the drop-down list for commands) and auto-save function. If your eyesight is not that good, you can use Mathcha - https://mathcha.io as it is a live LaTeX editor, i.e. you can directly edit the preview of math expressions with LaTeX instead of typing LaTeX code and then compiling it for preview.

If you are a perfectionist, do not fixate on the beauty of LaTeX, make sure you put enough effort into other courses and balance time well while you take this beast.

reviews.author: Minakami_Yuki
reviews.title: If you want it, then you'll have to take it. But you already knew that.
reviews.comment_content:
As an Honors Course, the content of MATH 1023 is indeed very difficult and challenging. It differs a lot from the mathematics you learn in secondary school and requires you to spend a lot of effort on thinking and understanding. You would need to prove a lot of things rather than just calculating them and you need to make sure every step is justified.

Even though the course is hard, it is worth taking since you can learn the 'real' mathematics and train your mathematical maturity. If you want to do a Math major, taking this course (and spending efforts on it) will definitely help you in your future study.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ivan is a kind professor, his English is clear and easy to follow. The teaching is good and the pace is reasonable. Nonetheless, I would suggest you go through the material by yourself before the class since you wouldn't have much time to think in class. It helps you with a better understanding.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you want a good grade and have no intention to do a Math major, I would recommend you take 1013 instead. Otherwise, I think you should take this course, regardless of the grade.

For your reference: I am a local student and attained level 5* in M2, have no prior knowledge other than the materials covered in M2 but still get an A-. Don't be too pessimistic, even though there are a lot of talented students taking this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 assignment per week. There are around 10 questions in each assignment. The time taken to complete the assignment really depends on your mathematical intuition, you can complete 1 question in several minutes if you think in the right way and you may also get stuck on 1 question for a whole day otherwise.

Apart from that, there is 1 tutorial per week and the questions are also very hard, I would recommend those who take the course study the questions before the tutorial, otherwise, you can hardly catch up with what TA is talking about.

Moreover, you have to spend a lot of time to fully understand the materials taught in class since this course has a strong emphasis on concepts and logic, you need to know why rather than how. To be specific, when studying the examples, ask yourself what is the reasoning behind those solutions rather than just knowing how the question is solved.

reviews.author: Candy626
reviews.title: Good Introduction to Calculus and Analysis (but you may get depression)
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers Chapter 1 and 2 of Professor Min Yan's MATH1023 Notes
1.1 Limit of Sequence
1.2 Rigorous Definition of Sequence Limit
1.3 Criterion for Convergence
1.4 Infinity
1.5 Limit of Function
1.6 Rigorous Definition of Function Limit
1.7 Continuity
------------------------------Midterm------------------------------
2.1 Linear Approximation
2.2 Property of Derivative
2.3 Application of Linear Approximation
2.4 Mean Value Theorem
2.5 High Order Approximation
2.6 Application of High Order Approximation
2.7 Numerical Application (Newton's Method was not taught)
--------------------------------Final--------------------------------
Professor Ip also included some of his own supplementary notes with extra proofs.
Basically a combination of MATH1013, MATH2033(MATH2043?) without integration, and about half of MATH2001.

Professor Ip will go through the lecture notes and 12 worksheets with us during lectures, and the TA will go through the 13 tutorial worksheets in the tutorials.

The content is as interesting as the difficulty of this course. Instead of just knowing how to do limits, differentiation, and remember certain theorems (what taught in 1013), I can actually know the reasoning and proofs behind.
As a local DSE student with neither math competition experience nor self-learned everything, I did feel extreme pain switching from M2 style computation-based math to MATH 1023 style rigorousness. However, it is quite satisfying once you can understand the theorems reasonably well (Doesn't need A+ level understanding to feel this satisfaction), basically opening a new world to you and make you view mathematics differently.

Slight criticism though:
The amount of content and level of difficulty (especially for Professor Ip's years) is a bit too much for a year 1 3-credit course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Obviously, the instructor is Professor Ip, or Ivan.
The TAs are Hiu Chi Sit and Yunhe Li.

There are 2 80 minutes lecture and 1 50 minutes tutorial per week.
There will be an extra final review session.
Attendence will not be taken and lecture recordings will be uploaded to Canvas immediately after the lecture, so feel free to skip a lesson if you are sick.
Professor Ip also opened a class discord server for us, so he can release information, discuss math, or even chat casually there.
Note that I attended all lectures and tutorials.

Professor Ip is a good teacher.
His voice is moderately loud and his tone is quite chill. His English is quite good and the accent is very audible. He handwrites notes using a digital note-taking application as he speaks, and his font is acceptable.
He is well prepared before he comes to class and knows the content well, and explanation of content is quite clear. Even if he made a mistake, he will make corrections as soon as possible.
His teaching speed is quite fast, but is still acceptable to me.
He often includes jokes and easter eggs (eg. uses anime scenes as his Zoom virtual background) suring lectures and in homework/ exams.
If you do not understand, Professor Ip welcomes anyone to ask questions after the lesson, he will explain all of them clearly (except for the time he rushed to the cinema to watch One Piece Film Red). You can also ask questions on the discord server, as Professor Ip replies very quickly (at most within few hours).
Bonus: As Professor Ip is also a musician, he often invites us to attend his concerts.
Bonus 2: If you want to, he also doesn't mind eating lunch/ dinner with his students. Feel free to invite him to LG7 and chat casually with him on math, music and ACG stuff.

My TA was Hiu Chi Sit, so I cannot comment on Yunhe Li.

Hiu Chi Sit is a good TA.
Sadly, as he is always very sleepy, his voice lacks energy and may be hypnotizing to some people (not to me though). His English is good, and the accent is very audible.
He handwrites notes using a digital note-taking application as he speaks, yet his font is slightly unclear but still readable.
Hiu Chi Sit can explain the tutorial questions quite clearly.
However, he also have the problem of teaching a bit too fast.
If you have questions, you can raise them anytime, and he do not mind answering them. And if you have a lot of problems, he will answer most of them (before he gets too tired) as he marks homework in the library/ LIFS common.
He is also a very caring TA, as he encouraged me to move forward and not compare with others after I told him I fried my mid term.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is very very good.

The grading scheme is as follows:
Homework: 20%
Midterm: 10-40%
Final: 40-70%
(Take the maximum of the weights)
Bonus overall course points will be given if:
You reported math related typos in notes, worksheets, or homework (0.2 points per typo, 2 points maximum).
You typed your homework using LaTex (0.2 points per homework, 2 points maximum).
You submitted a question in the final review session (1 points maximum).

Note that Professor Ip and the TAs mark our homework and exam quite leniently, you get a lot of partial credits even if you can't do half of the question.

Professor Ip adopts a partially-absolute grading system.
The mid term, final, and overall grade books are attached below, so I won't mention the grades too in-depth here.
For this semester's case, in short:
Overall score of 60% or above can get A-range
Overall score of 39.71% or above can get B-range
Overall score of 20% or above can get a passing grade.
(Mean overall score is at 52.78%, i.e. B+)
As you can see, the A-range and B-range are very wide.

I expected a B+ or maybe even B from the start, but still managed to get an A- even though I was below mean in the mid term. I was very surprised when I checked my grades, and I kind of think that I do not deserve an A- (please don't take it back though). I am truly grateful for Professor Ip's generosity.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is very heavy (to me).

There are 1 homework with 4 long questions (and an ungraded bonus question) almost weekly, and the deadlines are set 2 weeks after release.
In total, there are 10 homework.
The homework questions are mostly quite hard, so be prepared to spend a lot of time on them.
In fact, I spent most of my time on MATH1023.
Also, it is not a shame to work with your peers, so please ask your friends for help if you do not know how to do your homework.
As you do your homework, you most likely need to review the course contents, so it that you effectively studied a few times as you do your homework, but it is very time consuming.
Please be reminded that the bonus questions are usually very hard, sometimes even those who got A or above cannot solve them, so do not be frustrated if you failed to do some of them, you are already very good.
Moreover, LaTex is brand new to me, and I spent quite a lot of extra time typing my homework using it.
At the beginning, I usually use about 6 days for each homework, and eventually the time decreased to 3 to 4 days when I got used to the contents.

Besides homework, you also need to spend a lot of time to understand the concepts.
Again, don't be afraid to ask your friends/ professor/ TAs for help. I can understand most of the concepts only because I have knowledgeble friends and kind professor and TAs.
It should take at least 4 or 5 days of studying before each exam.

I know that some may do extra exercise (eg. Rudin's textbook, HKALE, etc.), but homework and revision already took up most of my time, so I did not have time to find any.

This course will mess with your study schedule, sleep schedule, reduce your freetime, and give you depression (since your classmates are very strong) to some extent, depending on your ability.
I personally sacrificed a lot of sleep time to finish the homework.

To (hopefully) decrease your workload in your first fall semester, please study HKALE Pure Mathematics/ mathematical analysis as soon as possible. Although it may not help you solve Professor Ip's extra hard questions, prestudying can certainly help you understand the concepts more easily.
In case you are about to take this course, please kindly remind your cute å¸«å¼Ÿå¸«å¦¹s, thankyou~

reviews.author: Kesehotum
reviews.title: Ivan best prof :D
reviews.comment_content:
Limit: limit of sequence, properties of limit, monotone sequence, Cauchy criterion, infinity, limit of function, continuous function, intermediate value theorem, invertible continuous function

Differentiation: linear approximation, derivative, properties of derivative, monotone function, extrema, means value theorem, high order approximation, high order derivative, Taylor expansion, convex function, sketch of graph, Newton's method

This course focuses greatly on conceptual understanding. Because of this, you avoid tedious calculations.

While this looks like a regular calculus course, it's actually an intro to math analysis in disguise. Check Ivan's meme below :P Everything is proven rigorously from the ground up.

I absolutely recommend enrolling in this course if you enjoy math, even if you're taking a different major.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Best prof!!!

Ivan is always well-prepared, so the lessons are organized very logically. While he generally bases his lectures on Yan Min's lecture notes, he sometimes rearranges certain parts to make the flow of ideas easier to understand.

He is also very engaging. He'll give time to ask questions whenever dealing with difficult concepts.

The pacing is very good. To maximize results though, it's best to go through the lesson beforehand, so you won't get lost. Additionally, there's a mid-class break, which is very nice.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade course.

Lots of A-range students since Ivan is generous.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework (10)
Midterm (1)
Final (1)

Ivan gives 1 homework per week for 10 weeks. They use rather nonstandard techniques which may take some time to get. While each has only 4 problems, you'll probably need to allot around 10 hours per homework if you really want to learn the lesson well. I think this workload is (sort of) expected since this is an honors course. Rest assured, you'll learn a lot from them.

It may prove difficult to study for the midterm and final since they test a wide variety of techniques. You may understand the concepts but still fail if you don't practice enough. Unless you're a genius, then just like Ivan, you'll find them trivial. Otherwise, I suggest you put in the time necessary to practice all sorts of problems related to the lessons learned.

reviews.author: hardplastic
reviews.comment_content:
Basically follows Yan Min's lecture notes with some extra knowledge added by Ivan in class (even some MATH 2043 content)

The difficulty of the content is much higher than the non-honour version (MATH1013), and is even harder than the same topics in HKALE pure math.

Only math genius or masochist should consider taking this course.

No matter what, the content in this course can really build up a strong sence of mathematical rigour, which is of upmost important if you want to be a math major
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ivan is a good teacher. He explained the theorems, and the logical relation between them very well. And you can always interact with him through discord. If you throw some question in discord, he will answer you very quickly.

TAs' are also good, expectially for their leniency in grading the HW and exam. I can see that they tried their best to save our marks
reviews.comment_grading:
In this course, you will compete with: IMO medalists, top math students around the world, best local math students, etc. If you are not one of them, don't expect your grade will be too good.
Yet, if you can get around the mean score, it still secure you a B+, which is very good grade actually.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite high.

It normally takes me a whole week to finish one assignment, but we got a new assignment evey week so i basically have no spare time. Expectially if you wanna get the bonus marks, you need to type your HW using latex, which basically doubled my time for doing the assignments coz I am not familiar with it.

reviews.author: humanppplus
reviews.title: Fruitful course taught by a professor obsessed with anime
reviews.comment_content:
MATH(2Â¹â°-1) is a mathematical analysis course disguised as a calculus course. If you are a (especially local) freshman reading this and will take Ivan's 1023 (probably happening again on year 2025), go self-study some HKALE Pure Maths before you start taking this course.

Before midterm:
- Limit of Sequences
- Rigorous Definition of Limit
- Monotone Convergence Theorem
- Cauchy's Criterion
- Bolzano-WeierstraÃŸ Theorem
- Divergence at Infinity
- Limit of Functions
- Rigorous Definition of Limit
- Continuity
- Intermediate Value Theorem

After midterm:
- Rigorous Definition of Differentiation
- Maximum / Minimum
- Mean Value Theorem
- L'HÃ´pital's Rule

Course based on YAN, Min's Lecture Note, but I don't think it is that useful... using Ivan's blackboard slides and watching his lecture videos is ok.

Very rewarding content
reviews.comment_teaching: Good teaching. Lazy to elaborate but Ivan is very good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grade.
40% of students get A range (44/110)
73.6% of students get B range or above (81/110)
As long as you study, you can get B range or above. Much much much much much much better grades than MATH1012/1013 (even MATH1013 L1 (MATH major session), their grades are BAD)
See the gradebook attached.

Grading method:
Total mark = sup{0.2*(Î£ Homework Score)/9.8 + Î±*(Midterm Score) + Î²*(Final Score) | Î±+Î²=0.8, Î± âˆˆ [0.1, 0.4], Î² âˆˆ [0.4, 0.7]} + Bonus Marks (Max. possible = 5)

Homework 1 full mark = 80, others = 100, so total = 980

Bonus Marks include
1) LaTeX-typed homework: 0.2 marks for each reasonably-typed LaTeX homework (max = 2)
2) Typo for bonus: 0.2 marks for each mistake you spot and report on the Lecture Note, Homework and Solutions (max = 2)
3) Final review question: Find one question for Ivan to do and explain to the class during the final review session (1)

Midterm:
Mean = 43.79/100, SD = 21.05, Max = 103/100, Min = 2/100
Final:
Mean = 46.37/100, SD = 18.95, Max = 97/100, Min = 8/100

I got 43 in midterm and 55 in final, ate an A- at last. Satisfied as a non-MATH student.

P.S. 103/100 in midterm and 97/100 in final is the same guy - and he is an SBM guy who just audits this course!! Crazy...
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely high workload. Ivan's homework is hell. Be prepared to spend â‰¥8 hours on each homework if your maths is so-so like me. But the homework problems are very rewarding and you'll defintitely learn a lot.

"Evil counterexample time :P" - Ivan, Homework 4 Q.2

10 homeworks in total, each homework includes 4 compulsory problems and an optional problem. Released every Friday (except the midterm week) and to be submitted 16 days later on a Sunday. 16 may seem a lot, but since a homework is released every week, in reality you only have 7 days to work on every problem set.

reviews.author: The_Pierrot
reviews.title: A quite descriptive review of the course? \Ivan/ \Ivan/ \Ivan/
reviews.comment_content:
Course Description:
"This is the first in the sequence MATH 1023 â€“ MATH 1024 of honors courses in one-variable calculus, with strong emphasis on rigorous mathematical reasoning.

This course will cover limit and differentiation.

Limit: limit of sequence, properties of limit, monotone sequence, Cauchy criterion, infinity, limit of function, continuous function, intermediate value theorem, invertible continuous function

Differentiation: linear approximation, derivative, properties of derivative, monotone function, extrema, means value theorem, high order approximation, high order derivative, Taylor expansion, convex function, sketch of graph, Newton's method"

As mentioned, this course focuses on Limits and Differentiation (Integration and Series will be done in MATH1024). What's special about this course is that it emphasizes on mathematical rigor, i.e. every statement should be precisely defined or logically sound (up to some assumptions); which means the MATH1023 will focus on these points:
Â· Motivation + Observations
Â· Conceptual Understanding
Â· Logical Definitions
Â· Theorems (+Proofs)
Â· Examples & Applications.

And as you can see, it is very different than MATH1012 or 1013 since they are both mostly focused on computations,which is why the course is highly recommended to those who are planning to do a maths major (specifically pure maths) or even doing theoretical physics.

This course is very different than school maths because it exposes you to the world of proofs and conceptual understanding of math, but it gives you a great learning experience that you won't find in any other course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ivan is a good teacher overall. He planned his lectures well and is very well aware about the order he should be explaining about.

In contrast to some lecturers who simply read and copy whatever the lecture notes says; Ivan, even though he uses the same lecture notes (Yan Min's lecture notes), it's clear that he puts a lot of effort in each lecture so that the session will go smoothly and fun. He's also open to questions, so don't be afraid to ask him some questions :)

In short, he is good at teaching and also a humorous guy where you can joke around with.
reviews.comment_grading:
Ivan gives two schemes in grading:
Homework = 20%
Midterm = 40% / 10%
Finals = 40% / 70%

So even if you screwed your midterms, you can still make a comeback in the finals by using the 10-70 scheme! (which I personally did). But Ivan is very generous in giving grades to his students even though the questions he gave are relatively hard, about 40% of the students are in A range, which is something... Here are some statistics:

Midterm grade distribution:
Out of 100
Mean = 43.38
SD = 21.05
Min = 2
Max = 103 (wtf)

Finals grade distribution:
Out of 100
Mean = 46.37
SD = 18.95
Min = 8
Max = 97 (wtf)

Overall grade distribution:
Out of 100
Mean = 52.78
SD = 21.93
Min = 1.06 (audit)
Max = 98.91 (also audit....)
reviews.comment_workload:
This is an Honors course, so it should be expected that the workload will NOT be light.

In Ivan's courses, he will give a homework in every week which consists of 4 questions (not including sub-questions + optional problem) that has a deadline of 2 weeks after the homework is released (but each homework is released every week, so the deadline is kind of 1 week -_-)

The questions Ivan gives are interesting, you probably have never seen those questions before, solving them might take some time (if you're an average student like me) but it does give more insights to the topic, and that is what makes Ivan's 1023 special.

Since this is an Honors course, please do make time to study if you want to have a high grade, learn from many different sources as possible, Ivan will NOT give exam questions that are like the homeworks, so you have to force yourself to be exposed to different and new questions to be prepared for his exam.

With all that, best of luck in your 1023 journey! ğŸ‘

reviews.author: maths 4ever
reviews.title: IVAN IP :P
reviews.comment_content:
IT IS REQUIREMENT FOR IRE TRACK IN MATHS

Recommend reference book: Principles  of mathematical analysis (by Rudin)(ch1,3,4,5)

Content:

Limit: limit of sequence, properties of limit, monotone sequence, Cauchy criterion, infinity, limit of function, continuous function, intermediate value theorem, invertible continuous function
â€”â€”â€” mid term â€”â€”â€”
Differentiation: linear approximation, derivative, properties of derivative, monotone function, extrema, means value theorem, high order approximation, high order derivative, Taylor expansion, convex function, sketch of graph, Newton's method

Comment:
Calculus (âŒ) analysis (âœ…)
It is somehow a introductory analysis course ( and harder than MATH2033 )
So I think it is good for anyone who is doubting if he/she want to study pure math in future
reviews.comment_teaching: Excellent, although some may think that he teaches too fast , he recorded his lecture so that we all can revise by watching his lectures video . Also , doing his homework can really learn some deeper maths which is interesting (eg counter examples :P) and can really clear concepts by doing this (although very hard)
reviews.comment_grading:
Take the maximum of the weights such that the total is 100%:

Homework 20%
Midterm Examination 10-40%
Final Examination 40-70%
Letter grades will be assigned depending on overall performance.
Obtaining a total point of 90% or above, or top 10%, will guarantee an A+.
Obtaining a total point of 70% or above will guarantee an A-range.
Obtaining a total point of 30% or above will guarantee a passing grade.

However it is very hard to get 70% in his exam  and mean is B+ (Estimated) seems so not bad I think

Mid term :
mean 43.8/103
sd 21.05/103
High 103/103 (yea insane)
Low 2/103
UQ:54/103
LQ:28/103

Final :
mean 46.4/100
sd 18.95/100
High 97/100 (same insane guy)
Low 8/100
UQ:62/100
LQ:34/100
reviews.comment_workload:
One really time to digest the content and it has a huge gap between dse M2(which is rubbish) and MATH1023
Also 1 assignment per week and difficultyâ€¦. Maybe me dumb I need about 10 hours per week to do that 4 questions (not included optional and latex) .

reviews.author: Drater
reviews.title: \Ivan/ \Ivan/ \Ivan/ Fun and Happiness :)
reviews.comment_content:
This is the first in the sequence MATH 1023 â€“ MATH 1024 of honors courses in one-variable calculus, with strong emphasis on rigorous mathematical reasoning.

This course will cover limit and differentiation.

Limit: limit of sequence, properties of limit, monotone sequence, Cauchy criterion, infinity, limit of function, continuous function, intermediate value theorem, invertible continuous function

Differentiation: linear approximation, derivative, properties of derivative, monotone function, extrema, means value theorem, high order approximation, high order derivative, Taylor expansion, convex function, sketch of graph, Newton's method
reviews.comment_teaching: Ivan's teaching pace is basically a video in 1.5x speed, if you can't catch up with his teaching speed it's okay, he always records his lectures so that you can review them afterwards, or skip the lecture overall, but it's not advised since Ivan is cute. Unlike some certain tao bao professor, he seldom refers to notes and books, instead every lesson he brings a bit of notes and explains the topics through examples and worksheets, which he then shows all the steps clearly on his ipad instead of the whiteboard.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 20%
Midterm Examination 10-40%
Final Examination 40-70%

Homework grading is pretty lenient, TA's are pretty sparing when it comes to marking our homework. If you homework is not graded by Ivan, chances are your minor mistakes won't be spotted.

The Midterm was hell (for me), it was the most braindead thing I have ever encountered, but suffering through the paper was fun.
reviews.comment_workload: New homework every week, deadline set in two weeks, and a total of 10 homework in this semester. All of them contains four question numbers and 2~4 subquestions (sometimes the subquestions are unrelated to each other, so some confusions might happen). The homework is rather hard and challenging, takes about four to five days of thinking for some of the questions. If it is Ivan, then good luck doing counter example questions.

reviews.author: SunGamePlay
reviews.title: \Ivan/ Excellent course for Math Major \Ivan/
reviews.comment_content:
Overall, the course it no as hard as many people though.
Trust yourself that you can do it.
Using Latex or finding typo would give you free bonus point.
The syllabus is listed in below for you to reference.

Limit and Differentiation (AND TONNY SUBWAY)

Limit
Limit of sequence
Rigorous Definition of Sequence Limit
Criterion for Convergence
Infinity
Limit of Function
Rigorous Definition of Function Limit
Continuity

Differentiation
Linear Approximation
Property of Derivative
Application of Linear Approximation
Mean Value Theorem
High Order Approximation
Application of High Order Approximation
Numerical Application

TONNY SUBWAY
Finding who is Tonny
Give him a free subway
Help him to cut the subway

Compared to MATH1013/1012, this course has fewer computation (good for those who have a lot of careless mistakes.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
\Ivan/\Ivan/\Ivan/
Ivan is almost the best professor among math department.
You donâ€™t need to worry about its English and writing.
(Not like some other professor)
He teaches things in detail clearly with fun.
Donâ€™t be shy to interact with him, you can talk to him
not only about academic but also anime (quite fun to do so)

You can try to guess the background of the Zoom recording.
It's from anime and changed weekly.
(But no bonus will be given even if you answer it correctly, just for fun)
reviews.comment_grading:
The ratio of Midterm and Final is related to your performance in both exam.

Method 1 : 20% HW + 40% Midterm + 40% Final
Method 2 : 20% HW + 10% Midterm + 70% Final
Final score = Maximum score using the 2 method

It is definitely a hidden good grade course,
(those who don't want you to get in to 1023
just don't want you have a good grade)
Just believe yourself that you can get a good grade here.

Half of the class obtained A range with the remaining obtained B range.
reviews.comment_workload:
You would receive homework every week and it is due on Sunday 2 weeks after, and the homework would delay for 1 week after midterm. There is a total of 10 homework and only the best 9 homework count for calculating the score.

Overall, the workload is low.
It only takes you a serval hours to do the homework and you can learn a lot during this process.
Don't hesitate to ask others or search in internet
to help you get a full marks.
(As I known, many people got a full marks here)

reviews.author: Joestar
reviews.title: Bad grade for more important concept
reviews.comment_content: The content Ivan prepared is more difficult than in MATH 1013 but in exchange, those concept taught has more depth with proofs, some of them will be taught in 2043 (Work hard in 1024), a class worth spending time to study deeper but may get a bad grade.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Come on, it's the Ivan Ip. Would the lecture be bored and feel confused?
Alright so, Ivan has a firm foundation on teaching this lesson and he did not just talk the concept, but also proved those concept well with supplementary notes, which helps the understanding of different theorems and their relationships.(Just I am stupid such that I did not understand his notes...Need to work hard)
reviews.comment_grading:
20% HW, 10-40% Midterm (Not that good in Midterm), 40%-70% Final
Just your reference to think whether it is acceptable.
Add:[90,100]/ top 10% A+, (70,90] A, >30% pass
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is acceptable for giving us 2 weeks to finish the homework, just a little hectic for updating HW at Friday but not a big deal.(1 HW includes uniform convergence teaching in 2043, that is so Ivan.)

reviews.author: Thanic
reviews.comment_content:
An introduction to proof based calculus. Sequence, limits, continuity, differentiation, mean value theorem, convexity etc.

It's a bit different from what you've learned in high school, which was computation based. A very good first course which gives you a taste of what you might expect in a pure mathematics curriculum. If you have done math competitions or other proof based math stuff before, you have a huge advantage in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: I personally think Prof. Ivan's teaching is very good. I personally found his lectures insightful and the lecture notes were great as well. Overall, the class was a positive experience and if you are fond of mathematics I think you will enjoy the teaching here.
reviews.comment_grading: The assignments and exams are brutally difficult if you haven't done any proofs before, but the grading is fair and lenient. It is an honors course, so even if your marks are bad you can still end up with a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The course workload is pretty high, I think 3 credit is too low for this course. You will cover a lot of material, and it is pretty difficult to consistently learn and do well in exams after learning.

reviews.author: biuter
reviews.title: Decent Course
reviews.comment_content: You can refer to Yan Min's book 1023+1024.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor XIONG really has the heart to teach us( he will share some motivating quotes with us and give us a moral lesson). But, he speaks in a monotone, and his pronunciation is not clear. I usually feel bored in the lesson. Overall, he is a nice guy and he is willing to answer your questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Using absolute grading with a slight curve.
reviews.comment_workload:
Group homework: usually 3-4 students in each group. One hw for each group in the whole course. Required one week to finish the hw.

You need to do tons of practice in the related books to get B or above.

reviews.author: ymchanao
reviews.title: If you are hardworking and fast enough, chances are that you are going to get A grade.
reviews.comment_content: Professor made use of various materials from Yan Min's book 1023+1024, Apostol's and Rudin's. He doesn't just read notes though, he write his own notes and proofs, which I found pretty accessible and elaborate.
reviews.comment_teaching: He's willing to answer questions from students in class and after class. He also explained concepts very thoroughly and made emphasis on important concepts to make sure students understand. He even made final review for us, how nice of him eh?
reviews.comment_grading:
HW: 5%
Quiz: 5%
Midterm: 35%
Final: 55%
Absolute grading: >90% in total means A grade

Students are divided in groups of 3-4 people for homework. They have to sbumit it in LaTeX and they get the same marks in all homework.

I scored very high in homework, quizzes and midterm but only average in final but I still got A grade. What that means is that it IS possible to score "low" mark in final and still achieve a satisfactory grade. Although I should note that you would have to score really high in midterm, I mean really high (for reference, I scored 97/100 in midterm).
reviews.comment_workload: Because it is a class with very large amount of students, I only had to submit one assignment in the whole course. You HAVE to do as many exercises in textbooks as possible though, as the professor himself said that he teaches FAST.

reviews.author: Data Reaper
reviews.comment_content:
Some basic knowledge about calculus
The content is fine. We use Yan Min's textbook as a reference.
It's mainly about the comprehension of the concepts.
Some techniques are taught and some of the problems from mt and final are based on these.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not quite satisfactory.
Prof. Xiong is really nice, but for me, his teaching is not quite satisfactory. Maybe because the contents are intuitive and abstract. It's noticeable that he tried hard to give examples and explain but I excepted more.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair.
Grading policy: 5% quiz, 10% homework, 35% midterm, 50% final
(Not quite sure about the grading policy, but )
I fail my midterm (67 out of 100, mean 59) but I did quite well in the final (91 out of 100). I almost got a full score on quizzes and homework. Finally, I received an A in math1023.
The grade is fair enough, as long as you pay attention to the content you will be fine.
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends.
Overall the workload is extremely low.
Your group only has to finish one homework throughout the semester.
There aren't any compulsory exercises.
But if you want to do well in the exams, you shall do your work.
Try to seek as many learning materials and don't stop doing exercise before you can handle the contents.

reviews.author: Tshen
reviews.title: NOT perfect but still worthy
reviews.comment_content:
XIONG is not good at teaching. I learn little from his lecture...

But the textbook written by Yan Min is wonderful and the materials he provided are useful for me.

In general, you'd better learn this course by yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: XIONG do weak in teaching. You should learn by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading: I think it's good. There are a lot of people get A range in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignment.

One homework  for practice a week. (But there is only one homework that we should submit)

As long as you are confident that you can get good grade in the exam, then there will be no assignments for you.

reviews.author: Zory
reviews.comment_content:
Calculus
+
a little bit mathematical analysis but much less than FF and Ivan
reviews.comment_teaching:
Neither mean value nor Darboux's theorem didn't even show up in the Final exam, which is unbelievable...
Also, since he used 3 teaching resources(his ppt, yan min, Apostol's mathematical analysis  ) and there may be conflict in some variable names and concepts.
Don't mention the 13th MC in the final exam is controversial and directly conflict with his ppt and ivan's summary...
reviews.comment_grading:
Honestly generous
A+ rate is higher than FF and Ivan I guess(so do A range?)
XMS gave a lot of MC (60/100) in midterm and final to let the score looks better.
reviews.comment_workload:
small since only once homework for 5% grading.
But self-practice is essential for better understanding.

reviews.author: Evanescence
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly about the rigorous proof of limit and contents relative to derivative, like mean-value theory, taylor expansion etc...
Before the midterm, we mainly focused on the limit, and the computation is not difficult if you master the methods he mentioned in class and tutorials.
However, the rigorous proof about the limit is similar to the content and difficulty of mathematical analysis.
Chapters concerning derivative stresses a lot on the taylor theory. So I advise you practice a lot to have a better understanding of the contents.  And if you master taylor theory well, I think you will master these  contents well.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is very nice and easy-going.
His teaching is very similar to his PPT and sometimes you can learn by yourself with his PPT supporting.
However, some rigorous proof is ignored, and to be honest, my system and foundation of calculus is not that satisfactory.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 27/50 (5%)
Homework 48/50(5%)
Midterm 92/100(35%)
Final 88/100(55%)
Eventual 88.1/100
Get an A+ Finally.
reviews.comment_workload:
I study about 1 hour per weak besides class in normal days.
And I spent 1-1.5 hours per day before the midterm and final, lasting about 1 week,.
Ps: I study mathematics Olympics before, so on average I don't spend too much time on this core.

reviews.author: UB0000
reviews.title: Only for Math students
reviews.comment_content:
Just typical content of MATH1023, which is listed clearly in YAN Min's book . You may refer to others, or google "MATH1023" for canvas of this course, where you can find the above-mentioned textbook tailor-made for MATH1023 by YAN Min.

However, I will say many contents are probably only useful for Math students. For others, MATH1013 is enough. Of course you may try if you are really interested in Math, but not because you score high in public exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Actually, I feel like Prof. Xiong tried to teach us well (subjective), but he clearly failed to do so (objective).  He failed to update his notes before the lecture, and speak out his note with a flat tone during his lecture. Many of my friends fell asleep in his lecture even they try not to do so.

The subjective opinion is based on the fact that he tried to encourage us with a short moral lesson designed by him and he tried to make some change after the mid-term, but I don't think the changes are significant.
reviews.comment_grading:
According to his instruction at the very beginning of the course:
HW: 5% Quiz: 5% Mid-term: 35% Final: 55%

My score:
HW: 47/50 (Every group get high) Quiz total: 38/50
Mid-term: 82/100   Final: 67/100 (I think 90% are related to computation in final, which is strange)
Grade: A-

(Btw I got 5* in HKDSE M2 in case you want to know, but it means nothing in this course)
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 1 group homework, 5 10-min quizzes, a mid-term and a final. However, you need to spend lots of time on self-practicing or self-study to get a better grade. I spent an hour or more everyday on this course.
I barely review his lecture notes, but spent my time on Yan Min's book, sometimes Apostol Mathematical Analysis and Rudin-Principles of mathematical analysis as Prof Xiong provided us the soft copy.

Herman Yeung's  HKALE Pure Math series may provide some help, but not much in my opinion.

reviews.author: CLæ˜¯äººç”Ÿ
reviews.title: Think Twice, Local Student
reviews.comment_content:
The course mainly included two topics:

Limit of sequence and function (Normal Calculation like in MATH 1013, Epsilon-delta Definition, Cauchy Criterion etc.)

Differentiation (MATH 1013 + Taylor Expansion + Convex Function Definition and Jensenâ€™s inequality etc.)

For DSE students, M2 can only help you with very very basic questions. You will experience "real Maths" (proofs and rigorous definitions) in this course. If you are really enthusiastic about Maths, you will enjoy the syllabus.

[WARNING]
Before enrolling on this course, please see the epsilon-delta definition of limit by yourself and do the past paper (LQ part, LQ part, LONG QUESTION PART, not the short question part remember) in attachment. If you can handle it, you are fine with 1023. If you cannot understand anything, think twice because you are risking your grade.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Xiong is a friendly guy. If you get any problem, just ask him (though he might not be able to reply to you immediately). However, his teaching is NOT so good - reading steps in his PPT without explaining clearly the intuitions behind those steps. You will need to self-study (= doing questions all day long) really hard to make yourself understand the methods of solving problems and making proofs.

TAs are NOT the ones who can help you. They are talented in Maths, and if you are not that talented like me, you will learn nearly nothing from TAs. But remember to go through tutorials notes several times - they are useful.
reviews.comment_grading:
[WARNING]
If you are locals, and you want to come here to get A range, stop your daydreaming and go back to 1013. This is not the place for you. 80% of your classmates are NDS, and they will put in an unbelievable amount of effort in this course. Without determination AND talent, A range is not for you.

Register 1023 ONLY IF you want to learn Math, AND you do not care for a bad grade (my local friends get a C, but if he went to 1013, I am sure he can get A range).

In this year, Prof. Xiong used absolute grading with slightly curving (he said this in the final exam paper-reviewing section).

HW 5% (1 for each group in the whole semester)
Quiz 5% (5 in total)
Midterm 35%
Final 55%
(in September, he said >90% will get you an A only)

If you really worked hard, but you are not so talented, you can get B, or B+ if lucky.
If you did not work hard, but you are talented, you can get A range.

Remember, MATH course is realistic and cruel. Talent matters. So if you are local, please think twice before registering for this course. For real.

================================
FYI, my DSE M2 got 5*, and in MATH 1023:
HW 5/5
Quiz 2.4/5
Midterm 52/100 (mean 59.22, max 97, min 16)
Final 75/100 (both MC and LQ above mean)
Grade: B+ (I really worked hard during the semester)

TBH, this is a good grade course, with mean equals to ~B/B+. But remember, when you get mean in this course, you can get A range in 1013 probably. Think twice.
reviews.comment_workload:
VERY HIGH.

In MATH 1023, there are tons of NDS, and they are monstrous. If you would like to get A range, you have to put in the tons-of-time effort. At least 8 hours a week in doing questions will ensure you a mean score (~B/B+ grade). And for hard questions, you can solve them only if you are really talented. Please be ready to understand the hopelessness in doing homework and exams.

Feeling hopeless is the norm. Please stay strong and positive if you are in this rabbit hole.

reviews.author: hw1817
reviews.title: If you want good grade, escape from honour course
reviews.comment_content:
This course mainly consists of three parts:
- Limit
~ Limit of sequence
* Definition and proving of limit of sequence (both intuitive and rigorous- i.e. Îµ language)
* Computation of limit of sequence (sandwich rule, order rule, subsequence etc)
* Criterion (Monotone sequence, Cauchy criterion)
* Divergence to infinity
~ Limit of function
* Definition and proving of limit of function and one-sided limit (both intuitive and rigorous- i.e. Î´-Îµ language)
* Relations with the limit of sequence
* Definition of continuity
* Intermediate value theorem
* computation of limit of composite and inverse function
- Differentiation
*  Linear approximation (rigorous definition)
* Definition of differentiation (both intuitive and rigorous)
*  Computation of derivatives
*  Mean value theorem (rigorous proving involved)
* L'Hospital's rule
* Taylor expansion
* Implicit differentiation and implicit linear approximation
* First derivative test, second derivative test and high derivative test
* Sketch of graph
* Convex function
* Newton's Method
- Completeness of real number

Textbooks: Yan Min textbook, Apostol, Rudin

As you can see, this course has so many things to study. I feel like studying pure mathematics, although I am only a student whose major is chemistry..........
reviews.comment_teaching: I totally can't understand what he has taught. He seldom explains why he can solves the problem and how to solve different types of problems. Hence, I got a score below mean in the midterm exam. The only thing reliable is the Yan Min textbook. Yan Min taught me a lot.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading policy:
HW : 5% (submit in groups. 4 people in one group. Each group only has to submit one homework in this course)
Quiz : 5% (1% each, 10 min for each quiz)
Midterm: 35% (2 hours)
Final: 55% (3 hours)

He claimed that he would use absolute grading at the first lesson. He even claimed that a student can get an A if and only if his/her score is >90%!

The difficult of midterm exam paper and final exam paper rises significantly, although the quality of his teaching has not rise so much.

My score:
HW: 47/50
Quiz: 35/50 (Mean: 31.2/50)
Midterm: 53/100 (Mean: 59.2/100)
Final: 82/100 (Mean: ~60-70)

Luckily, I got a B+ . I will not consider studying in Math 1024 or Math 1014 as I am only a chemistry major student.
reviews.comment_workload: For the workload of homework, it is not too heavy. Unfortunately, due to the poor teaching quality, I have to spend many time to read the Yan Min textbook. To make the condition even worse, Yan Min only provides the answer for some of the questions in Yan Min textbook. In conclusion, Wolfram Alpha is your good friend.

reviews.author: lmacchch
reviews.title: Don't know how to comment
reviews.comment_content: I think the content is OK, including limit and derivative.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think Professor Xiong has tried his best to teach the course, but due to his limited teaching ability, the overall teaching quality of the course is still quite bad.
reviews.comment_grading:
In fact, it's hard to give comment to the grading because I don't know others grades. I can only tell you the grading scheme as well as my grade for you to refer.
Grading: one group hw 5%
               5 quiz    1%each, total 5%
               midterm  35%
               final      55%
My scores: hw 47/50 (mean 47)
                  quiz 39/50(in total, mean around 30)
                  midterm 76/100(mean 60,sd17)
                  final 92/100 (mean 69)
And I get A+ in the end.
I think the most important part in Xiong's exam is the computation. To be honest, I am quite bad at prove but I get all the scores related to computation and I got A+ in the end. Therefore, my advice is, if you want to get good grades in Xiong's honor lesson, just try your best to get all marks related to computation!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload varies, depending on whether you'd like to learn it seriously. But the compulsory workload is very small, as the only compulsory workload is your team hw.

reviews.author: SmokingPuddle58
reviews.title: Danger ahead! Don't take the course if taught by Professor Xiong! Swap to 1013!!!
reviews.comment_content:
The course will be mainly talking about limits and derivatives.

Limit:
Rigorous definition of sequence and function limit(ipsilon and derta definition, ipsilon and N definition)(Very important)
Continuity

Derivative:
Computation of derivative
Linear approximation
Taylor's theorem
L'Hospitals rule
Convex functions
Curve sketching
Newton's method

For the textbook, professor uses different textbooks, including Yan Min's Calculus, baby rudin and lax calculus. Homework will come from those textbook.

For examination, the exam put focus on calculations but not proofings, 1023 can (probably) be renamed as "Honors calculational calculus I"
reviews.comment_teaching:
POOR TEACHING!!!

He only talks to his hand-written notes without further explaining. The only thing he answers to a question asked by a student is "Sorry, but I don't know how to answer this question yet" Professor Xiong develops our self learning ability, which is SUPERRrrrrrr useful in university life.

Also, the paper in which prof. Xiong set mainly focuses on calculation but not proofing. However, this is MATH1023, not MATH1013!!! How come there are more calculations than proofing.

You know why I am joining 1023? I come here to learn how to PROOOF, not application!!!!! After all, I gain nothing. I learnt no proofing, moreover, my grade is "rotten".

Regarding his quiz, hmm, more and more easier. There are totally 7 quizzes(0-6), and only Quiz 2-6 are graded. Quiz 2 and quiz 3 look like that we are doing proofs, however, the quiz become more and more easier! From quiz 3 onward, the quiz become more computational. Quiz 4 and quiz 6 are about calculating derivatives, while quiz 5 is about calculating limits. No more MVT, no more Taylor, no more ipsilon-derta language... The mean of the quiz becomes higher and higher! Unbelievable!
reviews.comment_grading:
ABSOLUTE GRADING!!!

He claimed that only >90% could have an A. I don't know how many people will get an A in his course as the mean for midterm was around 56.

Anyway, in his "moral lesson"(Half lesson), at least have known that "Grades are important, but not the most important."

Grading scheme:
HW: 5%
Quiz:1% each, totally 5 quizzes.
Mid-term:35%
Final:55%

I think I may not get a good grade.

I didn't perform well in mid-term as they are mainly about proofs, so I did a lot of exercises of mathematical analysis, hoping that I can do proofing questions better, however, the questions in final are mainly about applications, not many proofs and therefore again, I didn't perform well in final.(Hmm,It seems that I am finding excuses for myselfğŸ¤”)

===UPDATE ON 22/12 and 3/1===

Grades are out and I'm deciding to audit MATH1024 while taking MATH1014 for the next sem. I don't want such a course to lower my TGA. Choosing 1023 is my worst choice ever! It turned out that 1023 has the lowest letter grade in my 1st semesterğŸ˜¢. As I said, "After all, I gain nothing. I learnt no proofing, moreover, my grade is "rotten"."
reviews.comment_workload:
I don't know how is the workload. I'm very disappointed with this course. Hardworking doesn't pay(maybe) in prof.Xiong's course!ğŸ˜¢

I put a lot of time, revising MVT, revising Taylor's theorem, revising limits, but sadly, 3/4 long questions put focus on computation of derivative, curve sketching and optimization, which I did not revise so much. Hard-working does not guarantee a good grade. However, if you don't work hard, you will certainly get a bad grade!

reviews.comment_teaching:
Well, Xiong reads things with a more active tone than Google Translate, that's the reason that the instructor is not Ms. or Mr. Google but Prof. Xiong. For the other things? I don't know, maybe he offers some moral lessons, but I don't feel more comfortable but more anxious. Well, personally, Xiong is a kindhearted guy.

==================================================

Regarding the MC Q.13, I really have nothing to say but my fury. He didn't give a clear instruction regarding the question, but he insisted on the wrong answer, when I talked to him in his office, after an argument, he just simply said I didn't want to go for an argument with me, and let me out.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't know, as the grade has not been released yet, but guess what, he said that this year the grade is on an absolute grading, 90+ -> A, but the mean is 59 or something, so, you know it...

At last I eat B slightly below mean.
reviews.comment_workload: No, if you are a genius, you just need to complete the homework accounting for 5%. But I am not a fucking genius, I have Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder because of thinking those motherfucker mathematics questions and concepts days and nights helplessly, and guess what, none of them emerged in the fucking examination. God damn it, I should rather find a place to sleep.
