reviews.author: UnconMarketeers
reviews.comment_content: Follows Yan Min 1023+1024 Notes Ch1-2 (except Newtonsâ€™s Method lol). You can find it easily on the internet. FYI: You may get the link of course archive video by requesting him via email. But they will be removed once next 1023 course commences.
reviews.comment_teaching: Generally good - At least can make me clear up my mind. Also because of using zoom as teaching platform there was usually a polling question in each lecture - where sup(correct rate) < 100%. Theyâ€™re usually some basic conceptual question.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you get as many bonus points as possible, you will get an A range for around 70% of course total score. There is a range of weighting for each of homework, midterm and final, and the total score is the optimal one.

The possible ways to get bonus points include answering polling questions, using LaTeX to finish homework (submit both .pdf and .tex file - I lost the point once just because forgetting the .tex file) and finishing the bonus questing in the 4th hw, which is super complicated.
reviews.comment_workload:
10 homework for the whole course, as it should be the first experience to do LaTeX typing, you will spend much time to handle with it (well I believe it is still much time consuming than handwriting no matter your experience). The problems are sometimes complicated.

The last hw is the most impressive one - reading a wiki page of irrationality of pi and filling in the proof details. I really love this kind of hw style as I can deeply understand the proof after finishing it.

reviews.author: Wing Chan
reviews.comment_content:
The content are hard to many, but Fong's notes explained them very clearly and teach in an engaging way.
Suitable for students who are interesting in precise and analytical math. U will have a chance to trace back the entire development of limit and differentiation with this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Super good
He taught in a funny and engaging way. Welcome a lot of questions as well as mask to mask interaction upon booking during his office hours.
reviews.comment_grading:
Most students got A to B range.
Absolute grading. Reasonable grading systems.
reviews.comment_workload: 1HW per week. Quite heavy but they are essential for you to develop math sense on proving skills and application of theorem learn

reviews.author: letmegohome
reviews.title: Difficult
reviews.comment_content: Suitable for students who are really interested in math. For others I don't think this course suit you.
reviews.comment_teaching: Though FF is a humorous and nice professor, I don't think the content is organized well enough.
reviews.comment_grading: I took this course for a couple of days and then dropped it. So I can't provide accurate feedback. But my friend took this course and the grading is fine. But I don't think grading criteria can save you if you are not able to solve a single problem in the final.
reviews.comment_workload: Hw is allowed to be finished together by a team.

reviews.author: yarle
reviews.title: Good Experience
reviews.comment_content: Differential and Mathematical analysis( NO integral)
reviews.comment_teaching: FF is humorous and patient. He explains any question and tells jokes almost every class. It is hard to describe  unless you take his class.
reviews.comment_grading:
There will be 3 bonus in this class.
It consists of class questions(it's easy to get all correct), Latex(if you upload your assignments with Latex) and bonus questions in homework(Hard but not necessary because you can get full 3 points in the first two items)
The method to calculate grades is flexible.
For example,
10% assignments + 20% midterm + 70% final exam
OR
10% assignments + 40% midterm + 50% final exam
I think if you listen to classes seriously and finish all assignments by yourself, you can get good grades.

( FF will explain a lot in the first week, just drop it if you think it is too hard. But you won't!!!)
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends.
There will be only one assignment every week and there was no assignment at a week(FF said he wanted to make us relaxed at that week)
Every assignment has about 3 to 5 questions. And FF will upload assignments' PDF about two weeks in advance. It makes that someone maybe have finished them in advance but someone maybe be a DDL fighter.
Assignments are not hard but not easy. As long as you listen to his class carefully, it will take about 2 to 3 hours.( for me)
More important, you can do homework(not exams) with a group.
It means you can discuss with others and it really helps.
Sometimes FF will give bonus questions. HARD

reviews.author: lyc0816
reviews.comment_content: You can check others' comments because it's quite the same as before. The lecture will follow the lecture note and you SHOULD read it before the lecture because those who attend this class are soooo smart and the teaching will be very fast, mostly focus on proof and explaination.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Fung is really interesting and knowledgeable that every question he can explain in a clear and fast way. He also interacts with us by chatting in our chat room and share some cool stuff. Very good teacher and he is very passionate about math!
reviews.comment_grading: Well, you have to submit your hand-write homework to canvas mostly every week. And the grading was done by the TA and sometimes you don't know how it's grade. But the final grade is still quite fair I think.
reviews.comment_workload:
Every week will have a set of HW and you can do it by yourself or team-up. Believe me, that is heavy work.
For me, it's a little hard to both finish the work on time and also digests what the professor has taught.

reviews.author: C8763
reviews.comment_content:
It's an introduction to analysis, so the content is quite hard. Computation isn't a thing here because we are all doing proofs all day long.

Take this course only if you plan to major in mathematics (advanced pure math track) or physics. If not, this course would be quite tough for you.

Also, I wish the TAs could mark our work faster.

See syllabus for more details.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching is quite interesting. Initially I just want to drop the course but because of his teaching, I stayed.

Also, he would have some stupid in-class-questions to test your understanding, these count toward your bonus points.
reviews.comment_grading: ok la (see grade book)
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely heavy. There are 9 compulsory and 1 optional problem sets, the questions are hard af. Be prepared to spend hours if not days on one problem set.

Luckily, FF allowed us to form groups of 3 to complete one problem set. (Of course you can be a solo player like Kirito)

reviews.author: Barbatos
reviews.comment_content:
1. Limit of real sequence;
2. Criteria of convergence (monotone-bounded & Cauchy, while neither proof was given until the last lecture);
3. Limit of real function, composition rule and Heine's rule (i.e. the characterisation of function limit using sequence limit);
4. Continuity and properties of continuous function (IVT, EVT, etc.);
5. First order derivative as linear approximation;
6. Mean value theorems, L'Hopital rule;
7. Higher order derivative and higher order approximation using polynomials (i.e. Taylor's polynomial);
8. Convex and concave function, Jensen's inequality;
9. Smooth function and real analytic function.

One thing I like the most is how derivative is introduced in this course. The approximation approach is really intuitive and makes Taylor's polynomial natural to derive. I personally do not see this course as a course in mathematical analysis since not even the completeness of R was (frequently) mentioned with its importance emphasised till the last lecture. It will be even better if more elements of analysis and topology (of metric space at least) are added to the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Fong is really dedicated and beloved. He is really good at explaining concepts and his lectures are way more useful than Prof. Yan's textbook (ç¬‘ã„). If you are interested, you can google 'MATH 1023 canvas' to find the canvas site for 2020-21 fall and earlier which has been made public.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading: 75% above for an A while 95% above for an A+.
Try to get full mark for homework (which is not that hard if you work in a team and discuss with others) and write as detailed as possible in midterm and final. When a problem is really hard to give a rigorous proof using proper notations, write down your rough idea.
reviews.comment_workload: There were 9 sets of graded problems which had been quite time consuming. The workload could be doubled if you decide to type the answers in Latex.

reviews.author: Chino
reviews.comment_content:
the course gives detailed proof on every theorem used in the course.
The contents basically are the following
1. definition of sequence and function limit
2. continuity
3. intermediate value theorem
4. differentiation and linear approximation
5. mean value theorem
6. L'Hospital rule
7. Taylor expansion and real analytic function
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Fong is a humorous and nice person, he makes his best to make his teaching easy to understand and encourages us to think more about each theorem and proof. It is great to have his lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
it depends on how hard you work.
Finishing and understand all the homework problems plus the tutorial problems should promise you B/B+ grades.
Try to read more about AL math and also past year HW and exam should also help you to aim higher.
the grading is
max{Î» homework+Î¼ midterm+Î½ final:
Î» âˆˆ [0, 20%], Î¼ âˆˆ [0, 40%], Î½ âˆˆ [40%, 70%], Î» + Î¼ + Î½ = 100%}.
So final could help you a lot if you didn't perform well in the midterm.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is low if you only care about those 'must'. 1 HW assignment each work with around 3 to 5 questions. It is easy to tackle if you pay attention to the lectures. Also, you could ask prof Fong or TA if you have any problems.
However only completing those HW assignments might be not enough for you to aim high in the final exam, you might need extra practice every day to get prepared for the exam.

reviews.author: tuboshu
reviews.comment_content:
The contents mostly followed the order in the text notes written by Yan Min: Limit, Limit of function, Differentiation, MVT IVT, Taylor expansion......

Prof added some challenging problems originated from some researches(e.g. prove that Î  is irrational by using only 1023 contents)  which were interesting(at least i think so)
reviews.comment_teaching: fofo teaches really good. i can see that he triggered many students' interests in mathematics(including me), and most 1023 students have expressed their will to continue studying in 1024 next sem.
reviews.comment_grading:
He gives nearly 30-40% students A-range in this course(30+/120+), which is really nice for an honor course.

For me, i got 72/100 in midterm(mean:59),  73/100 in final(mean:55),  mostly 100% score for each assignments, and some bonus from polling questions and challenging problems.
So final grade: 79.48/100  A
reviews.comment_workload: Maybe 10 assignments in total for the whole semester. Therefore, you might need to pay more to fully understand those contents by yourself.

reviews.author: Weewee
reviews.title: Good course for those who are interested in mathematics and don't mind a bad grade
reviews.comment_content:
1. Intuitive Limit of Sequences
2. Rigorous Limit of Sequences
3. Monotone bounded and Cauchy Sequences
4. Limits of Functions
5. Continuity
6. Intermediate Value Theorem
7. Mean Value Theorem
8. Derivatives
9. L'Hopital's Rule
10. Taylor Series
11. Lagrange Remainder Theorem

There were also other things that FF added in to his pleasure, such as little-o notation, linear approximation, Cauchy mean value theorem, and some supplementary proofs for different theorems.

For those who want to take this course, I strongly recommend you self-study some HKALE Pure Maths. Although the content of this course is beyond the scope of HKALE Pure Maths, it is better to expose yourself to those concepts first, other than diving into them rigorously straight on. Moreover, some HKALE Pure Maths concepts are treated as trivial, and used often, such as the AM-GM inequality, triangle inequality, and various algebraic manipulation skills.

I got a 5* in 2020 HKDSE M2, and I can assure you that M2 is absolutely useless as a prerequisite. This course focuses more on proofs than computation. Instead of finding the limit, you need to prove the limit exists, which is completely different.
reviews.comment_teaching: FF tries very hard to ensure that everyone understands what he is talking about, and answers questions as comprehensively as he can. Of course, due to the nature of this course, "trivial" steps to solution are sometimes left out. FF's lectures are enjoyable, and he sometimes cracks out a few awkward jokes, pressuring us to laugh. I only missed 3 lectures. Moreover, FF is very close to students, as he even organizes "extra-curricular activities" for students to join.
reviews.comment_grading:
Extremely beautiful grade.

HW: 394/450
MT: 48/100
FL: 63/100
Bonus: 2.25/3
Overall Grade: B+

To prepare for exams, redoing your homework problems is the best. I didn't touch any exercises on the suggested textbooks FF provided, and only redid the homework.

To be honest, I think it is impossible for anyone who hadn't learnt the content of 1023 already to get A range (or at least learnt HKALE Pure Maths). Switching from "unrigorous" maths to rigorous maths is a mind-blowing experience.
reviews.comment_workload:
One problem set would be given every 1.5 weeks on average, depending on the mood of FF. Each problem set contains 3 to 6 questions, also depending on the mood of FF. There are a total of 9 "compulsory" homework (not really compulsory, since you can choose for the weighting of homework to be 0%), and 1 bonus homework. Bonus marks are given for those homework submitted with Latex.

Sometimes, FF adds contemporary unsolved mathematical challenges into the homework, hoping some prodigy would solve it. Other times, FF may pull inspiration from his own published papers or HKALE past paper questions.

Truth be told, the homework are fun to solve, but not fun to do (I never thought Intermediate Value Theorem could be so hard). But overall, the homework helps me understand what the heck is going. As a deadline fighter, I would finish the homework at the day the homework was due.

You can team up with other people for the homework, with at most 3 people I think, and your team would share the homework score. Be sure to find a teammate who is good at real analysis. FF may spare you some hints if you ask him kindly enough (or annoy him with sufficient tenacity).

Tutorial exercises can be neglected, I doubt they help with the exam at all.

reviews.author: Five
reviews.title: More appropriate for who are good at Math already
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite understandable if you have learned Calculus at your highschool. I only read lecture notes and not attend the tutorial session. Anyway, you should attend all of the class to get bonus points, can make a "+" for your grade. The content in exams not really hard if you often do the calculus problems during the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. FONG is really good at explaining the concept (I think ?) because I see there are lots of students asking and they seem to satisfy with prof. Fong's answers. The only thing that annoys me a little bit is his pronunciation of words such as "bound" or "infinity".
reviews.comment_grading: Prof. FONG has a strange way to grade students that helps everyone have more final grade than usual. If you want to have an A+, you should withdraw no more than 1 part in each of your exams., and complete all of your homework, of course.
reviews.comment_workload: I think the required workload is quite comfortable. Prof. FONG has some extra suggested problems if you want to practice. So I can say the better grade you desire, the more workload you should have.

reviews.author: |Tan>
reviews.title: A very intriguing first year math course
reviews.comment_content:
Sequence limit
Monotone sequence
Cauchy sequence
Function limit
Continuity
Derivative
Mean Value Theorem
Taylor approximation
Lagrange Remainder theorem
Convexity, Concavity
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Fong's teaching is easy to understand as he makes use of descriptive figures and really thinks with students, from simple topics to more complicated ones. He is also funny and ready to listen to our questions, no matter how silly or irrelevant they are. Students are also able to ask questions and discuss with each other via group chat on Discord or WeChat, and professor Fong also spent his time responding to messages there.

There are also very useful tutorial lectures where the TAs will give you some example questions. These questions are distributed on Friday each week and you are advised to think about them during weekend.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme: max{Î» homework+Î¼ midterm+Î½ final:
Î» âˆˆ [0, 20%], Î¼ âˆˆ [0, 40%], Î½ âˆˆ [40%, 70%], Î» + Î¼ + Î½ = 100%}.

Absolute grading: A+ about 95% or above, A about 80% or above, A- about 75% or above.

MATH 1023 this year is conducted through Zoom, so professor Fong made used of the Polling function in each lecture to test our understanding. These polling questions are easy but you need to focus on the lecture. Each correct answer in the Polling question will be awarded 0.1 points (on 100.0) in the total score.

There are also bonus scores for LaTeX-typed assignments (0.1 each, given that you submit both .tex file and .pdf file) and a very hard problem in Homework 4.
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework: There are 9 graded assignments (Homework 1-9) and 1 P/F assignment (Homework 10 (or X)). You are advised to check the problems in Prof Min Yan's notes be fore attempting these assignments since they maybe challenging. You can form groups of maximum 3 people to submit a homework.

Midterm & Final exams: Questions with ideas developed from the lectures and assignments.

You can visit the Canvas course website to know more. You can enter through professor Frederick Fong's personal webpage. Exam papers, assignments, main lecture and tutorial lecture notes and several useful materials are available here.

reviews.author: OJ
reviews.comment_content: The content is really informative and concrete, professor will cover and proved all the theorem used in the lecture so as to help you established a concrete picture about calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Fong is really good at teaching, he will start form something really easy (easy than dse M2), and building up to more difficult problems with many example(relate to how to used the theorem).Therefore as long as you pay full attention you can understand all the thing in the lecture even you got level 4 in M2(just like me).
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite good, nearly half of the student get A range (actually more A than A-).The course adopt a absolute grading so you do not need to worrying having many very strong classmates.Especially, the professor will give quite a lot of bonus and partial point so it is not very difficult to get a satisfactory grade.;
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is relatively high, you will have a homework per week that can be handling with 2 more grpmate(strongly advised to have grpmates) and tutorial exercise for practice.

reviews.author: JoWL
reviews.comment_content: The course outline is based on the note written by Min Yan, which could be found on the internet. It basically covers limit of sequence and function and differentiation. The course is more focusing on rigorous mathematical reasoning, which means it is more analysis like. Also, it introduces more propositions and theorems than MATH1013. You may find this course interesting if you are interested in the deeper layer of calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is quite logical cause it follows the flow of the lecture notes. For the guys who only learn M2 stuff in use, it is better to be prepared before lecture. The professor is willing to answer you problem.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good. If u are above mean, you are guaranteed with a B+ grade.

Grading system:
20% HW
30% Mid-term Exam
50% Final Exam

The Mid-term Exam is extremely difficult. So no need worry man, if you score high, you are perfect. If you fail, u are probably at the median, or just not far from it.
reviews.comment_workload: Although there is just one assignment (4 graded questions) every week. Some of the questions are quite challenging which spend you hour of time. But you should try to figure them on your own rather than seeking help (from google/baidu).

reviews.author: Hay7777
reviews.title: Good.
reviews.comment_content: It is fun if you want to know more in maths, or maybe majoring in maths, perhaps. I would say it will be useful for your math life. The major difference from math1013 is the rigorous definition part, it requires time to digest if you have not listen to it before.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ip is funny, and he has done his very good job to teach, at least we understand almost everything from his lecture. When you have questions, you can also ask him during lecture, or maybe email him, he is helpful.
reviews.comment_grading: It is not bad comparing to other course, the curve is relatively low tho, because it is a honors course, and yeah people score low in midterms and finals comparing to math1013.
reviews.comment_workload: Not many things to do, homework once per two weeks, 4 questions per homework, but it needs time to think of how to do, not just applying what you have learnt in class like math1013, but also quite large workload to understand, but still only 3 credits, which professor ip thinks that it is not a only-3-credit-course lol.

reviews.author: jackyfghjk
reviews.comment_content: Useful content, including a lot of rigorous proof based on m2 or m1 calculus. And much more difficult compared to high school calculus. Everyone in the class is an expert and they know some of the theorems already
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof IP explains well in detail. There is a break in the middle of the lecture, he will answer our question during the break and after the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: I get around 30/100 in final, still get C+
reviews.comment_workload: Homework only 3-4 question, it is quite difficult for me, but most people get around 90 to 95%

reviews.comment_content:
Limit: limit of sequence, properties of limit, monotone sequence, Cauchy criterion, infinity, limit of function, continuous function, intermediate value theorem, invertible continuous function

Differentiation: linear approximation, derivative, properties of derivative, monotone function, extrema, means value theorem, high order approximation, high order derivative, Taylor expansion, convex function, sketch of graph, Newton's method (not important)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is a genius and has a strong knowledge in math, which means he thinks everyone is a genius and can understand everything as many things are trivial and obvious in his point of view. Sometimes, he doesnâ€™t understand the difficulty that stupid people (just like me) have. Even so, he still answered questions raised by students patiently.

If you really donâ€™t understand what he is talking about in class, I think you can just skip lectures and do self-learning. All lectures will be recorded and you can watch them after you have gained enough basic knowledge to understand what he is talking about.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grades are surprisingly good. About half of the class got A-range.

In this semester, the professor allowed us to change the weighting W so that the final score was calculated with the following formula
20%Homework+(80-W)%Midterm+W%Final+BounsPoints(maximum 5 marks),
where W âˆˆ[10,70]âˆ©N.
reviews.comment_workload:
You will have a piece of homework with 4 problems which are really difficult. As Iâ€™m a stupid person, I had to spend a few hours doing each problem. As a result, every weekend was killed.
The midterm and final exams were both extremely difficult (only for this year because of Ivan Ip). You may have to be very mature in math so as to get a high score in each exam.

reviews.author: yuezhuosc
reviews.title: Quite a good honor class in general
reviews.comment_content: This course focuses more on proof and definitions instead of calculating and application, and you will learn a lot after each session, so it is a good choice for those who are interested in math or would like to take related majors. On the other hand, this course is definitely difficult (with a mean of 40 in midterm and 50 in final), so if you just want to gain three credits and satisfy the course requirement, please go to math1013.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching of this course is satisfactory, with high quality teaching materials, both by Ivan and Yan Ming. But there are still some small problems:
1. The solution of worksheet pages is sometimes difficult to understand due to the irregular writing.
2. The tutorials usually spend too much time on review of last lectures, thus the TAs cannot finish the questions posted. I think the tutorials should attach more importance to problem-solving training.
reviews.comment_grading: Although the paper is difficult, the grade of this course is surprisingly great, and over 60% of students get a A range mark. If you follow the instructions of Ivan and do your homework carefully, I think you can easily get a A or A+ grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Undoubtedly the homework of this course is difficult and may consume a lot of spare time, but this also helps me to have a better control of knowledge leant in the lecture. At the same time, the problems posted is quite worth dealing with, and you will gain a huge sense of acommplishment after completing the homework. By and large, providing that the 'HONOR' title of this course, the workload of this course is reasonable and accprtable.

Final mean is 51 and i got 60

reviews.comment_workload: There is very very difficult homework each weeks. It is so hard that u can hardly finish it unless u got someone else helping  and discussing

reviews.author: ruozhilaji
reviews.title: Great Course
reviews.comment_content:
The main reference is written by Prof.YAN, but the exercise on it might have a different style with the questions in tutorials, assignments, and exams.
During the lecture, Ivan spent most of the time proving theorems as described in the course description.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ivan is really patient and glad to answer your question even at midnight.
reviews.comment_grading: If you did focus on the course, your grade will not be bad. Surprisingly great!
reviews.comment_workload: Because I did not participate in Olympiad Competiton and just learned for JEE, I think the workload is quite huge for me. It always takes me 10 hours to finish each assignment. BUT, I think it is worth it.

reviews.author: Squidgy
reviews.title: Good grade if u work hard
reviews.comment_content:
Rigorous proof of sequence and function limitation
Differentiation and Derivative
Rigorous proof of differentiation
Taylor series
Draw some functions
btw I think the course is special at its worksheets and tutorials questions. Those practices rly improve my math a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think Ivan tries to teach well, but the language ability restrains him. He often speaks lower and lower during the lecture, and the concept he wants to explain may be vague. I think most of the professors in Math department have this problem so...
reviews.comment_grading:
I think Ivan is quiet lenient at giving good grades.
assignments 20% (10 assignments)
midterm+final=(80-W)+W
You can choose your W. W is ranged in [10,70]
Midterm mean:43/100
Final mean:51/100
Gradebook is attached.
reviews.comment_workload:
I think in first semester everyone should have many free time.
If you choose this course, all those time will be fucked up, and you'll need to spend hours to finish the assignments. I could definitely say that the workload is heavy (not including those IMOs)
However, I think the content is worthy of studying. The course provides you a stable background of calculus. Even though you are not interesting in majoring Math, it's still good for you to reg it.

reviews.author: Daniel Kao
reviews.comment_content: The content was helpful for a student interested in doing math research. For those who don't have enough confidence, do not challenge for this course. It focused on the proof of the theorems and questions instead of the application of calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor had a terrible English accent, and the way he explained an idea was not clear enough, so sometimes it was a little bit hard to understand what he wanna talk about.
reviews.comment_grading: The mean of the midterm was only 43..., it's tough lolll.
reviews.comment_workload: There was a paper including 4 main questions every week, taking me about 7 hours to complete and understand each one on average.

reviews.author: Alanine
reviews.title: good course
reviews.comment_content: really deeper content about calculus
reviews.comment_teaching: not bad, he is not teaching really fast, so everyone can catch up easily.
reviews.comment_grading: good grade, don't worry that if you are below mean or what, as the grading is too good, even you are below mean, you probably still get an A- or B+.
reviews.comment_workload: not much, 1hw a week, each hw have around 10 questions. the questions are quite hard actually, u can try to do it on your own but I recommend u do it with helps from internet or the textbook.

reviews.author: Noil
reviews.comment_content: honors calculus
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof.Xiong is an adorable teacher. He can explain things   clearly. All the points are well-written and easy to understand. even if you missed some class, you can make up by looking at the notes. he is helpful, enthusiastic to answer questions and easy to access.
reviews.comment_grading: students can easily get a rather satisfying grade (almost 40% students can get A range). This course is still quite competitive.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is acceptable. you will have 5-10 questions per week as your assignment. But you need to pay extra effort to finish the practice on the textbook.

reviews.author: llleo
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly talks about limit and differentiation.
The concept of limit is kind of abstract, but you may handle it after doing some exercise. However the differentiation is just regular staff.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Xiong is patient and willing to answer the questions. The teaching is clear enough, but not interesting. Most of the time he just strictly fellow the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is great. I think more than 50% of the students got A range.
Both midterm and final are not difficult. Most of the problems are of textbook level, so just do the exercise and you'll be fine.
reviews.comment_workload: One homework per week ,each has about 10 problems. The homework problems are really difficult, you have to spend a lot of time on it. However the problems are very good and you will learned a lot if you pay a lot of time to figure them out.

reviews.comment_teaching: He taught really well and you would see that he did put lots of time and effort in this course. He did want to let all of us have a good understanding of calculus.
reviews.comment_grading: I went to every lecture and finished my homework carefully than I got A.
reviews.comment_workload: Just read the textbook carefully and go to lectures, think actively and you will understand all the content.

reviews.author: Raiymbek718
reviews.comment_content: This course specialised on deep understanding of math. Course materials are introduced very well in the textbook and everything seems logical. Homework are the hardest part of the course some of the problems require a good skills in using math induction and other problem solving skills. Before the midterm you will be learning sequences and after it you will learn derivatives and Taylor expansion.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is mostly based on your self learning. I don't fill that lectures were really useful to me and all the material of the lecture is posted later on canvas. Tutorials are somewhere useful because they give you a sample of how to solve the problems, but so does the textbook.
TA's are useful if you have some problems during the course you can always ask them to help you.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading here is really fair, I think. Most of the class are really good in math. I have completely failed my exams i got 45/90 on midterm and 75/90 on final, because of the silly mistakes and thought that I was in trouble, but got B at the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is bigger than at most of the calculus courses, you should handle the homework every week and learn the course material by yourself and do a lot of exercises in textbook to be fine at the exams. But exams are not so hard as they might seem, homework problems are much harder than the exam.
Also it takes a lot of time on understanding concepts of complicated things such as numerical methods and rigorous definition of sequence. So if you have a lot of credits in your year 1, it's better to take 1013.

reviews.author: ZHANG YICHEN
reviews.comment_content:
Sequence
Limit and continuity
Extreme value theorem
Intermediate value theorem
Derivatives and differentiation rules,
Mean value theorem,
l'HÃ´pital's rule,
Taylor expansion, and applications of derivatives
reviews.comment_teaching: Since YAN Min no longer teaches this course, the workload and grading of MATH 1023 become much better. Xiong Maosheng, now in charge of this course, is a young, energetic and devoted professor. Though Xiong's teaching skills can still be improved, it is quite obvious that he is trying hard to teach his students well. In my humble opinion, he's doing reasonably well in teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: Xiong's grading is extremely well - almost half of the students got A range in MATH 1023 course taught by him in 2018-19 fall term.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is lighter than before under Xiong's teaching. Most of the workload comes from reading the textbook written by Yan Min; as for homework and exams, the questions are really simple in comparison with the questions in textbooks. As long as you work hard enough on the content covered in this course, a good grade is ensured. If you really want to learn something, rather than just to get a good grade, you should put a lot more effort in this course.

reviews.author: StevenSHC
reviews.title: A quite nice course
reviews.comment_content: Comparing to the MATH1013, this course focuses more on the proof. So in this course, you can have a deeper understanding of the theorems and the formulas. I recommend the students who want to pursue deeper knowledge in maths to enroll in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Xiong, a professor from mainland China, is a very nice person. His course is quite interesting. Although the teaching process was a bit slower than the plan, it was not a big problem.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade of this course(10%Homework, 30%Midterm, 60%Final) is very very good. I didn't do well in the final exam(below mean). But I still get an A range.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload really depends on how hard you want to learn maths. The homework is not much. But if you do all the exercises on the book, which is highly recommended by prof, the workload will be quite large.

reviews.author: Androe
reviews.comment_content: It covered the knowledge of limit and diffrentiation.
reviews.comment_teaching: It's a little bit boring to me, to be honest. The teacher just gave some examples and told us how to solve them. However, the tutorial can be quite interesting, as long as you have a harmonious relationship with your TA.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is really really good! If you are above mean, you will certainly attain A range!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite big, that is to say, the biggest in my courses of that semester. But it is worthwhile to the grade finally!

reviews.author: Zechidlin
reviews.comment_content:
Basic concepts and calculations about single-variable calculus. Main focused on limits (before mid-term) and differentiation.
Have to say that compared to the same math course offered in Mainland universities...our progress is a little too slow. When my high school classmates finished series, we were still focusing on Taylor!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Personally I think the professor is quite good and is always willing to answer your questions. However, his oral English isnâ€™t very fluent,but is enough for understanding.
The only problem is that he depends too much on textbook. Almost all examples are from the book and there are few supplementary materials.
TA is nice. In my session, the language used in class finally turned out to be mandarin, which made it feel like in ordinary mainland class.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading... Iâ€™ve heard that itâ€™s quite fascinating. Actually,after the final score was released, I was concerning about whether itâ€™s possible or not to get a high grade. It finally turned out that this kind of worry is totally unnecessary. Both exams are easy to deal with and seems like >90% guarantees your A+.

hws(10%)

reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload. Compared to workload of math subject when in high school, itâ€™s even a little lighter. Anyway, itâ€™s just an introductory course and the difficulty level isnâ€™t as high as past.
Strongly suggest self-learning.After all, your grades mainly depend on your self-discipline.

reviews.author: Shimmer
reviews.title: Unexpected Good Grades
reviews.comment_content: This course covers limits (mainly before mid-term) and differentation (after mid-term). Compared to MATH 1013, it emphasizes more on rigorous proof and less on application. Detailed infomation can be found in other reviews.
reviews.comment_teaching:
"Any questions?"
"So far so good?"
"Let's have a short break."
Each class we'd heard the three sentences and they became the symbol of the course. The professor was mild and careful, though he sometimes made mistakes when writing examples. He solved every single problem with rich details and explained every new concept without any step omitted.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Assignment: 10%
Mid-term: 30%
Final: 60%

Overall I must say the grading is really good and maybe much better than that in previous years. The means of both mid-term and final are 80/100 or so, much higher than last year. However, I got an A+ with a score at 94.7.
reviews.comment_workload: I guess math can never be mastered with light workload... There weren't much assignment, but many execises were listed after each section in the textbook. You could work on fewer than 10 problems a week, but if you really want to learn something, maybe most of the exercises in the textbook should be finished.

Great algebraic skills are expected to have before study the course

Exam Mean: 84.85

Only 2 questions of each assignment is graded

With 1 mid term and final exam

reviews.author: Howardli621
reviews.title: A very good grade honor course
reviews.comment_content:
Content before midterm focuses on the rigorous definition of limit of sequence and function so you should make sure that you are extremely familiar with the Îµ-Î´ language and capable of writing proofs instead of simply computing. This is quite different from what we have learnt in high school maths so we have a hard time at the beginning of the course to understand all the content completely.
Soon after the midterm we started the second chapter of the textbook, which is written by professor Yan Min and prof. Xiong just keep saying that the textbook is very good and strongly recommend us to do all exercises in it. After the midterm we focus on differentiation. Content is quite similar to the HKALE syllabus (except Taylor series was seemed to be excluded since 1994) but slightly more in depth because proofs will be taught in most circumstances.
The content is quite useful for those who are interested in major in maths, especially pure maths, since the content in the course is simply introduction to real analysis which you will encounter in year2 if you take MATHS2043.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would say the teaching is fair. The professor simply extracted examples in the textbook and did it once in the lecture.The proficiency of the English for him is also fair, itâ€™s understandable  but with some Chinese accent. Sometimes it would be more efficient to study by yourself and skip the lecture. I sometimes skipped the lecture( in 10 a.m.) as I didnâ€™t sleep last night (perhaps because I am more efficient at midnight). However it all depends on different people so you should consider this very carefully.
  I skipped all tutorials so I am not going to give some comments on it (probably because I canâ€™t get adapted to the TAâ€™s accent)
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say the grading is very very very good.(Itâ€™s very important so I say it three times)
HW:10%
There are usually 6-10 problems in the weekly homework, half of it is straight-forward while the other half requires some deep-thinking. The TA will only mark the two easiest problem.
Midterm 30%
All questions are quite straight forward except a 3mark sub-question asking you to give an example of a sequence so that for any rational number, there is a subsequence convergent to it. I spent more time on this 3mark-question than that on the other 97marks
Final 60%
The whole paper is straight forward and you may even see the exactly same question in the textbook!

Mean for my tutorial class
HW: around 9-9.5/10
Midterm:~80/100
Final:~82/100
Overall:~82/100
I got full marks in all HW, midterm and final and eventually got an A+
I have heard that slightly above 90% in total score would get you an A+
84% or above in total score would get you an A
Most student in the class got an A range
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload depends on how serious you take this course.
The weekly assignment would usually take up 2-10hours for you to finish, depending on how difficult are the problems and whether you persist to get all problems perfectly correct even you know that the harder problems will never be marked (and indeed itâ€™s quite unfair to hardworking students)
This 3credit course takes up 38% of my total workload and so the workload is indeed quite heavy if you persist to know everything very well. Personally I spent quite a lot of time on studying the first 3chapters of Maths 2043 so I can get to know the proofs of everything that is not included in this course like Cauchy Criterion and some more abstract examples.

reviews.author: Doraemon
reviews.title: Challenging but well-structured and rigorous
reviews.comment_content:
The course mainly focuses on limits and differentiation. Major topics covered are the epsilon-delta definition of limits, the convergence of sequences, L'Hopital's rule, and Taylor's expansion. Unlike MATH1013 or high school mathematics, proofs are more emphasized in this course. The course content is similar to what was required in Pure Mathematics of the former HKALE exam.

This course is recommended to students who intend to pursue a research or academic career in Mathematics, OR those who have background knowledge about single-variable calculus. If you registered this course ONLY because you met the prerequisite (HKDSE M2 5 or above), you will have a very hard time studying this course.

No textbook from the market is required. The course covers the first two chapters of the textbook Calculus written by Prof. Min Yan.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Xiong simply read the textbook, copied some examples on it, and delivered the most basic material in his lectures. Far from adequate to complete your homework or excel in exams. However, he is a kind instructor who is glad to respond to your questions.

Thus, it may be a bit more efficient to read the textbook yourself without attending lectures and find him during his office hours only if you encounter some questions when doing self-study.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading policy is as follows:

Homework 10% (10 assignments in total, each worth 1%)
Mid-term 30%
Final 60%

As the grades from the Math Dept grading system are announced according to the tutorial section, below are the statistics for mid-term and final exams for my tutorial section only:

Mid-term:
Mean=76.40/100

Final:
Mean=84.85/100

Overall:
Mean=82.20/100
reviews.comment_workload:
Not as heavy as expected.

A piece of written homework with about 6 to 8 questions is assigned every week. In each homework, there are usually standard questions which you can complete as long as you attended lectures or read through the textbook. The remaining half will require much more thinking than what was needed to complete your high school homework. As a mathematics lover, I do enjoy thinking on those more difficult problems. But do expect that you have to spend hours on just one question on the homework.

For exams, I would say both the mid-term and final exams are pretty standard, so I believe that you can score pretty well as long as you have done the exercise. Though Prof. Xiong recommended us to do ALL the exercise in Prof. Yan's textbook, I have NOT done so because there are really too many repetitive questions in the textbook. Just do enough so that you can understand the concept and get familiar with the computations. Not worthwhile to do all if taken into account the law of diminishing marginal return.

reviews.author: couch_potato
reviews.title: Quite enjoyable to sit for substituting MATH1013
reviews.comment_content:
Local students: EVEN IF YOU GET 5*/5** IN HKDSE CORE & M2, THIS IS STILL IMPOSSIBLY DIFFICULT. DO NOT BE TEMPTED INTO ENROLLING IN THIS COURSE UNLESS YOU KNOW A LOT ABOUT OUT-SYL STUFF!!

The content focuses on rigorous proving by the epsilon-delta concept, piling an equal amount of time on limits and differentiation.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor isn't very presentable, to be honest. Xiong is very reliant on the Calculus book written by Prof. Yan Min, and can sometimes be confused during teaching, showing that he is not that well prepared for the lectures. However, I am promoting him to B because of a very funny way of explaining the concept of "tangent": a straight line that kiss the curve in a perfect way. After lecture we pestered the professor about the explanation for normal!
reviews.comment_grading:
To declare my status, I only sat this course, I did not enroll in it.
From discussions I overheard and some friends who I met at this course, the grading is rather lenient, with a lot of A range, since this is an honors course.
You will usually see IRE students and non-local students like GCE A-level students and NDS in the course, while locals are rare.
reviews.comment_workload:
Immensely heavy workload.
The regular HW for this course is very difficult. You need a lot of time on each question, and each HW has quite a few questions. When the instructor postponed the deadline of one of the assignments due to cancellation of lesson by a typhoon, the whole class cheered for a few seconds, and the instructor had to intervene to resume order in the class.

reviews.author: Dcture
reviews.title: difficult but USEFUL
reviews.comment_content: the content is quite similar to high school's but focus more on rigorous proof than application. it was interesting for me to know the reasons behind every theory.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr. Xiong is really patient but sometimes goes so fast that I could not follow him well. He sticks really close to the textbook and occasionally made me feel unnecessary to attend the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
It depends to TAs actually. The TA that I had was strict and needed me to be extremely rigorous.
Midterm and final exams are not too hard especially compared to MATH1023 in the previous years.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 homework per week and not too difficult. This workload is really light compared to GAOKAO.
However, to get a higher grade, the professor strongly encouraged us to finish ALL exercises in the textbook and if you do so, workload could be heavy.

reviews.author: StupidChiki
reviews.title: Challenging Course
reviews.comment_content: The content of the lecture is very deep and it is much harder than MATH 1013, for those who have a good back ground in math, I suggest you take this course and learn many new things in here also you can sharpen your problem solving skill in here.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr.Xiong will try to answer all the question that we ask to him and he is quite a nice guy, but he only copy the text book to his lecture notes and most of them are the same.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is quite good (bell curve) but there is so many mainland student so be careful (think twice before taking this course!)
reviews.comment_workload: 1 week = 1 HW not so heavy if you try to do it 1 - 2 days before the deadline. Usually Mr.Xiong will give the homework at the last lecture of the week and the deadline is on the next week first lecture

reviews.author: Olivia.ss10
reviews.title: Naghh, It just fine
reviews.comment_content:
Similar to the high school Calculus,but explore more in depth.
It will be a more theory and proving math class rather than calculating number.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A little bit unorganized but he is trying his best to explain the detials.
He is willing to answer all the questions that you asked.
He is funny but not shown on his teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
As long you do your work, it will show fairly.
If you study hard on the exercise booklet and attend all the tutorials, you can absolutely well handle the midterm exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Mainly depend on yourself.

reviews.author: Tabibito
reviews.title: an Interesting but difficult course
reviews.comment_content: The content is great and very interesting. It is very different from MATH1013. The course first talked about sequence and series and some rigorous proof about them. You need to very good at logical thinking to cope with most of the problem in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Pro. Fong is a good teacher. The teaching speed is okay and he will answer you if you ask valuable questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good overall. Around 40% of the students get A range. But you should be careful because most of the students in this class are very clever. Therefore, it is reasonable to have so many students get A range. However, it doesn't really mean you can get A range very easily in this course because you have to compete with all these monsters. If you get into this course, you should understand theorems and use them effectively.

There is midterm, final and a lot of homework/ problem sets. The grading will consider all of them.

I got a B grade in this course but I got 50 in the total score.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite heavy compared to other courses because you will have more than 10 problems set in this course and their difficulties are much higher than webwork of MATH1013. Every problem set requires you to prepare it for 2 days? ((it is possible you do finish them in a day but that will be very difficult.

reviews.author: Trafalgar
reviews.title: Good Course to improve logistic
reviews.comment_content: Professor FONG is a very cute and nice instructor. He can explain things very clearly and is very patient in teaching. His homework can very nicely guide student to learn new things.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is great. His spoken English is good. And he uses ipad to teach so that every one can see the process very clearly.
reviews.comment_grading: Good. If you study hard on the homework and tutorial, you can do well in the exam. If you can get 79% overall you can get A.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite heavy. Every week there are 5 questions and I need to spend about 10 hours on it.

reviews.title: Especially suitable for those who have some competition experience
reviews.comment_content:
Limitation and Derivative. The content are similar with 1013. The only difference is the content is deeper and the homework is harder.
It might be hard to caught up this course if your math is not well enough. But if you want to study pure math or learn more, this class will be helpful.
THINK TWICE before you enroll into this course. Not suitable for those who want to major in chemistry or biology.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very interesting instructor who tells many jokes in class. He prefers to use no ppt and only writes on his iPad during the class (but enough).
The TA is also helpful. (but he may be angry if no one respond to him in tutorial sections)
reviews.comment_grading:
40% of A range. Seems to be very much, but remember you are competing with IMO medalists. If you do not require too much for this course (not A+), then the grade will not be so bad.
(If you want higher grades and you are not so confident with your math, maybe 1013 is better)
reviews.comment_workload:
The homework are challenging(the main challenge for this course) and time-consuming. Be prepared to devote most of your time in this course.(But it worth for your future study)
The preparations for the exams don't occupy a lot of time if you accomplish the homework.

reviews.title: excellent
reviews.comment_content:
same as yanming's note. home work contains 2 part.
1. text book excercise
2. extra excercise
first one is for peer checking
second is for TA checking
the second mostly decides the grade you will get for HM
but taht not means you needn't to do part 1
reviews.comment_teaching: really wonderful. everything seems easy to solve, and you can learn the method but not only the sollution
reviews.comment_grading: you can get excellent grade if you learn really hard,or you have talent in math is the same.
reviews.comment_workload: emmmm....a little bit havy, especially if you use latex for hm==

reviews.author: Khalil
reviews.title: Professor is very interesting
reviews.comment_content: Teaching progress was not fast which covers the main part of differential. The course went deep into the concept of fundamental calculus, forming a solid foundation for students to carry out higher level mathematical learning. During the course the related calculus knowledge was taught with some typical example which was easy to follow and some attractive and interesting expand knowledge such as Legendre polynomials  was also taught in class, making the course more "rich and colorful"
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor FONG, Tsz Ho is very interesting and humorous who always articulate points of knowledge clearly by combing some university-life-relevant jokes with mathematical concepts. The professor is also very kind and patient that you can feel free to ask any of the question relavant to the course. His teaching method is also commendable which focus more on the connection between knowledge of different chapters.
Since the professor was once a student in HKUST, he will know more about the problems that students might come across and give more appropriate advice on students' study.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 2 different scoring method in this course: you can either choose to take your midterm score into your grading with a full mark of 100% or you can decide to count your final grade only by the final exam with a scoring limit of 95%.
Since it is an honr course, I think the grading is pretty much fair. As long as you finish all the homework seriously and carefully on time and get a good mark in both the midterm and final exam, it will not be hard to get an A.
Be careful that homework is very important and do not miss the midterm exam if you want to get an A+(it will be impossible for you to compete with some IMO medalists or something like that with only 95% in total)
reviews.comment_workload:
Every week you will have to finish an assignment with probably 10 questions from the textbook (Peer review) and 6 extra grading questions. It will not be that much if you do not leave it until deadline.
Only midterm and final exam and there will be no quiz.

reviews.author: ç¿°å¢¨
reviews.title: choose it if you have some background in calculus...
reviews.comment_content: Well, I am very glad to have chosen this course. Because I think I can really learn something. Like Prof. Fong suggested, studying math 1013 is kind of waste, if you have studied calculus before.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Fong's class is quite interesting, and he really is struggling to teach you better. But TA aren't always that helpful. Their problems are sometimes weird, and things you learned in class aren't helpful when solving them.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is acceptable. Prof. Fong used several incentives to simplify the process of grading the homework, which in turn would give you more credits in the final grading. While the grade of homework depends on which TA is responsible for you.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite heavy, but once you get the point, you will feel better. And if you choose not to hand in the homework in the form of Latex, then the workload is lighter again. However using latex will give you bonus. In fact spending hours of effort in the course is quite normal.

reviews.author: XXM
reviews.title: A review from a science student
reviews.comment_content:
We can obviously tell by the Prof's teaching that his materials are carefully selected from the previous Prof. Yan's note.
The lecture notes are beautifully written and uploaded in time. Compared to the homework and exercises, they are relatively easy and fundamental.
The tutorial notes are the less serious and more interesting part of the course. XD
reviews.comment_teaching:
Honestly, this course is absolutely the best in my first sem.
Mr. Fong is not only humorous but has been behaving quite professional, logical and reliable during the whole semester.
reviews.comment_grading:
Students in this course can't really come to an agreement on this topic.
But for me, Prof. FONG's grading was reasonable.
In fact he's always been reasonable and considerate in many aspect.(Just refer to how he differed each sub-grade in the attachment)

I get 82 for both midterm and final, with an ok-level homework(about mean, I guess.) and a little bit bonus, and end up with a safe A.

I assume this column is in fact asking what effort is needed to get a good grade. I'd directly quote what the Prof said.

Study Tips for MATH 1023

Rule of Thumb for all university MATH courses (not just 1023)

Put continuous effort in the course throughout the semester! Understand all fundamental concepts by regularly attending lectures, reading lecture notes, and discussing with teaching staff and classmates. Develop your mathematical maturity and problem-solving skills through exercises and homework. Don't expect you can skip all lectures or exercises, and then "çˆ†seed" by intensive/overnight revision the day before the exams! It is impossible to absorb all course materials in just one night.

(see the meaning of "çˆ†seed" here (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site.)

Be critical

Don't just learn math superficially by memorizing formulae or by following homework solutions blindly. University level math, especially this honor course, emphasizes much more on logical thinking than high school math. Always ask for the reasons and make sure you are able to justify every step. Don't feel satisfied by just asking "how", but ask also "why", "what if", "under what conditions", "what's good", etc. To get started, you should first change the mindset that learning math is not about memorizing or doing routine calculations.

Be logical

When you learn a theorem, don't just look at the "formula part". It is more important to keep in mind the necessary conditions and hypotheses in order to apply those theorem. For instance, look at the statement:
LaTeX: \displaystyle\text{If } \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L \text { and } \lim_{x \to a} g(x) = M, \text{ then } \lim_{x \to a} f(x) + g(x) = L + M. If  lim x â†’ a   f ( x ) = L  and  lim x â†’ a   g ( x ) = M ,  then  lim x â†’ a   f ( x ) + g ( x ) = L + M .  
Many high school students would just memorize the rule that:
LaTeX: \displaystyle{\lim_{x\to a} f(x) + g(x) = \lim_{x \to a} f(x) + \lim_{x \to a}g(x)} lim x â†’ a   f ( x ) + g ( x ) = lim x â†’ a   f ( x ) + lim x â†’ a   g ( x )   
but ignore the assumption that both LaTeX: \displaystyle\lim_{x \to a} f(x) \text{ and } \lim_{x \to a} g(x) lim x â†’ a   f ( x )  and  lim x â†’ a   g ( x )   have to exist (and finite) in order to make use of this rule.

In this course, you should always pay attention to the assumptions and conditions of a theorem. Ask yourself whether the theorem would fail if these conditions are not met. Furthermore, such a condition or assumption must be used somewhere in the proof, ask yourself where this condition appears in the proof and why it is needed!

Be a good listener

While my lectures will be based on the lecture notes, they are not merely the "audio" version of the notes. By just reading the lecture notes, you may only learn how to do math, but in lectures/tutorials you will learn why math is done that way, and in the long-run you will also learn the way of thinking of the instructor and TAs. Therefore, try to focus on listening and thinking during class. Taking notes (blindly) may hinder your thoughts. All blackboard notes written during a lecture will be recorded in a PDF that you can check it up later.

Work smart (not just work hard)

Learning mathematics -- just like learning "ä¹é™°çœŸç¶“" -- requires intensive practicing, deciphering, but not just passively by quick reading (though mathematics is not like "è‘µèŠ±å¯¶å…¸" that you need to "sacrifice" in order to learn it). Do relevant exercises soon after a lecture. Work hard and do more exercises than assigned; but work smart -- don't just do exercises of the same type over and over again. After you feel confident with basic and routine problems, go deeper on more structured and thought-provoking problems to broaden your knowledge and skills. Don't just do ALL exercises in ONE book, but do SOME exercises in SEVERAL books. Kenneth Ross's book on Elementary Analysis is a good one. Some structured problems of the deceased HKALE Pure Math were very well written -- that you can learn something new in a "guided" way.

Learn from people

Math is not fun if you learn it alone. Form a small group (such as with your highschool-mates, o'camp group-mates) to study the course together. Whenever you find difficulty in a homework problem, discuss it with your friends first to exchange ideas. If the problem is still not resolved, ask instructors and TAs for hint. If you are afraid of finding the instructor and TAs alone, go together with your group.
