reviews.author: å°æ™º
reviews.comment_content:
The content is Calculus, which emphasized on the rigorous of mathematical deductions. For local students I personally thinks it takes time to adjust, as we are get used to simple computational mathematics. The content is similar to analysis. Some topics include:
rigorous definition of limits (which is kind of fun actually), differentiation, linear approximation etc. I learnt not a lot of new things, but certainly deepened my understanding towards calculus.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In general I think the teaching by Prof. Fong is quite good. You are welcomed to ask questions during the break in the lessons (I think). I did not attend much lessons though (less than 5 I think), but I encourage you to attend lessons.

Another good thing is that lecture videos and handwritten (on his pad) notes are provided which are vital for revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite good.
I got around 57/100 in Midterm. (Mean: 55)
and 79/100 in Finals. (Mean: 65. 47)

And I got A- eventually. (If I did my Homework better the grade would be A, but anyway)

Although the atmosphere is kind of competitive, I think as long as you finish the exam and the homework your grade should be alright. (I think professor has mentioned it is around 4x% A range)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is kind of heavy. Though later I found those to be kind of rewarding, like the success in doing maths. You have to submit assignments weekly/biweekly (depends), and the first part is questions from the book (which should be easy), and the second is the actual questions (which is more challenging).

Some of my friends spend hours on doing homework, but sometimes hints will be released in case the professor thinks it is necessary.

Type using LaTex will have a bonus of 0.1 per assignment, but I tried it twice and it used a lot of time.

reviews.author: Kin Aun
reviews.title: Nice course. Competitive
reviews.comment_content: The course covers Limit (Sequence Limit, Rigorous Definition, Criterion for Convergence, Infinity, Function Limit, Continuity) and Differentiation (Linear Approximation and its Application, Property of Derivative, Mean Value Theorem, High Order Approximation and its Application). Lecture notes very nice and complete.
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear presentation. Good sense of humor. Discussed a lot of useful examples in lectures. Focus on mathematical knowledge rather than just exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme A: Midterm 35%, Final 40%, Homework 22%, Peer Review 3%.
Scheme B: Final 70%, Homework 22%, Peer Review 3%.
Both midterm and final are open-booked (doesn't really help a lot). Not enough time for both midterm and final. Have to practice on speed.

There was a quiz. The first 5 people who submitted complete solution will get bonus marks. (#1 gets 0.5, #2 gets 0.4, etc)

0.1 bonus point will be given for each HW submitted in LaTeX, a total of 1 bonus point possible to obtain. In my opinions, the bonus points really matter but LaTeX will further consume much more time.

Anonymous grade book attached down there.
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy workload. 1 problem set per week, total 10 (the last one doesn't count but gives bonus 1 point to the total mark if get 70% in the HW). Each problem set has 4-12 part A questions and 3-7 part B questions.

Part A is the 3% Peer Review, not graded by TA but will be given to 2 other students to leave comments (point out mistakes and misconceptions). Part B is the 22% Homework. Problems in Part B are really hard and time-consuming. Some of the concepts or tricks used in the Homework problems will be tested again in the midterm and final.

reviews.author: Mauricio
reviews.comment_content: The course covers the first two chapters of Prof. Min Yan's Calculus lecture notes(which can be easily found online). I am not a great fan of this notes as the examples don't contain the questions, just the solution so you have to guess what the problem was. The first part of the course is on limits and the rigorous definition, and the second part is on differentiation, and its applications. Everything is built from scratch, as there is no prerequisite, other than mathematical maturity. This course is aimed at students with interests in math or physics as majors.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Proffesor is really good, he always came prepared with slides which will be left in canvas for future reference. Although the lectures can help giving an insight all the material can be lerned from reading the lecture notes only. Plus lectures are recorded so if you are really good you can take the privilege of skiping them.

Tutorials have some really interesting questions to practice problem solving skills, but attendance is not required. In fact they even said that if you can solve them by yourself there is really no reason for you to attend tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework is 22% and Peer review(you have to check other students work) is 3%
For final and midterm there are 2 options.
Midterm 35% & Final 40%
or scrapping your midterm and taking your final as 70%
This allows for a good grade even if you score really low in the midterm.
In my case since I got 56 in midterm and 86 in final I took final as 70%. In total I got 83% which gave me an A.
Grading is pretty good as most people get B and above although the class can be really challenging for the less experienced in proof writing and problem solving.
reviews.comment_workload: Other than peer review which shouldn't take long, the workload is the problem sets you have to solve for each week. They consist of part A which is usually straightforward computatons and part B which is more in-depth proof based problems. This can take usually more than 2 hours in solving and a lot more time if you are typing them in latex for 0.1 bonus marks. This is porblems are key to this course since the ideas in the exams will be derived from them. There was also a bonus problem set worth one extra mark.

reviews.author: iwantarange
reviews.title: Interesting
reviews.comment_content: A first-year math course with some approaches in analysis (eg rigorous definition of sequence/function limit), which is quite useful if you are going to major in math.
reviews.comment_teaching: With well-written lecture slides and his interesting way of teaching, it is not hard for most students to catch up his teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: This year's grade is quite good due to some IMO medalists. Prof Fong decided to give better grades to us. According to the gradebook, getting about 80% in course total gives you an A, and most students have B range or above. For details, check the statistics attached in other comments.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is moderate. Although the quantity is not too much when compared to Prof Yan's 1023, the difficulty of the problems are quite high, which many students spend a lot of time (ie >3hours per week) in order to finish the homework.

reviews.author: xdlok
reviews.title: Good grade course if you are good in the first place
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm:(Rigorous) definition of limit of sequence, sandwich theorem, monotone convergence theorem, Cauchy Sequence, (rigorous) definition of function limits

After midterm: Continuity, IVT; Differentiation, linear approximation, implicit differentiation, MVT, L'Hopital's Rule, taylor series, higher derivative test, concavity and Jensen's Inequality.

    (Almost) Everything is derived from scratch so no prior knowledge is needed (in the sense that it won't help), but mathematical maturity is a must, and you will definitely develop that from homeworks and tutorials.

    This course really encourages thinking the logic and proof behind everything instead of doing boring computations (we do have some though).  We started by assuming only the most basic rules (like arithmetic rule of limits), and then use the rigorous definition to build up everything. It makes you think twice on any seemingly easy question, and think of what you actually did, instead of skipping steps all over like what I did in DSE.

    I had a friend asking me about a limit problem and I explained to him the arithmetic rule, and the composition rule, and he don't understand. He said: What are all those rules? I didn't use those rules and I got the answer anyways. I said: You said you didn't use it because you don't know you are using it. That's why you get things wrong. You just assumes things and blindly use it (like the L'Hopital's Rule). Taking MATH 1023 really made me more careful when doing problems.

    (Some contents actually overlap with MATH 2033 so if you have made your way to the end of 1023, you should have an easier time in that. Professor said that some of our content is actually harder.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching is good. He often make jokes in lectures which helped (at least) me focus. We often have breaks in between so we can digest what he just said and we can ask questions as well.

    One time he devoted the whole lecture talking about the application of IVT, albeit not quite related to the course, is definitely interesting if you like maths.

    Keep in mind that the homework is much more difficult than the lectures, and professor said that the learning really only begins in the homework.

    The tutorials are ok. Sometimes the TA prepared some questions that he have no idea how to solve, or need to use clueless complicated stuff to solve. And he sometimes can't finish the notes. There are good questions in the tutorial though.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 Schemes: 22% HW, 3% peer review ( if your reviews are ok and no one reported you then you should be fine), (35% Midterm and 40% Final) or (70% Final), whichever are higher. There are bonus if you type your homework in LaTeX (0.1 overall/homework), one bonus question (for the first five answered correctly),one bonus problem set (iPhone X eh I mean Problem set X) and some bonus if you give good reviews (idk who got it)

Midterm (over 100 marks,)
Mean: 55.07, Median:55.5, Highest: 100

Finals (over 100 marks,)
Mean: 65.47, Median: 64, Highest: 100 (6 students)

    For me, I got 69 marks in midterm and 89 marks in finals, so I actually used scheme B (the all-in-final scheme) and got an A. Nobody fails but one do get a D.

    But don't get fooled by the seeming good grade because you will get rekt by xue ba and IMO medalist! Only come if you really wanted to study (pure) math in the future (or if you are masochistic. In that case go for it! You do you!)
reviews.comment_workload:
If you feel like that this course is for you, then think twice. The workload is really heavy. Overall 9 problem sets (1 bonus problem set), and each consists of several computation problems (can be hard), and several high difficulty questions, then I can only say that no one can help you , not even google, except for our lord savior professor Fong or TAs.

    I spent at least 8-10 hours on each homework. (Almost) Every Thursday and Friday night I would be just hating my life, but finishing those questions give you that sense of satisfaction and joy (that's right) when you finally think of the trick needed, or done the question, that MATH 1003/1012/1013 would never be able to give you. Until next week and the cycle continues.

    If you want to pwn this course, what are you smoking? But if you really do, you really need to spend time into not only the homework, but also the problems in Prof. Yan's notes, which would help you clear your concepts and learn some tricks, and extra exercise from other references.

    If you think that you can overcome the homework (don't overlook their difficulty and time required!), then definitely take this course. You will not regret it.

    Oh and by the way, the midterms and finals are open-notes and you can bring 2 notebooks, and you can use a calculator as well! Not that any of that are useful, but hey. Copy down all homework solutions ( and digest them) and you will be set for both.

reviews.author: TERAON
reviews.title: é‡‘çŸ³è‰¯è¨€ for DSE students
reviews.comment_content:
1. Limit of Sequences, Squeeze Theorem
2. Rigorous Definition of Sequential Limits
3. Monotone Sequences, Cauchy Sequences
4. Infinity, Limit of Functions
5. Rigorous Definition of Function Limits
6. Rigorous Definition of Function Limits, Continuity
7. Continuity
8. Derivatives, Differentiability
9. Chain Rule, Implicit Differentiations
10. Monotonicity, First Derivative Test
11. Mean Value Theorem, Lâ€™Hospitalâ€™s Rule
12. Taylor Series, Higher-order Taylor Approximation
13. Higher Derivative Test, Convexity and Concavity

Copying from Professor Frederick: "Overall, 1023 demands much more on logical and critical thinking, and mature mathematical skills."

For example, to rigorously prove that \lim{x \to a, a^x} = 1, where a > 0 and hence a^x is continuous at 0. (See the attachments.)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Frederick is a well explainer. He is also efficient and organized that he like to post all the solutions immediately after the deadlines or the exams.

In terms of the teaching materials, Professor Frederick uses electronic hand-written slides (see the attachments) based on a 347-page lecture note written by Prof. Min YAN which even him does not read it. Also, there are lecture videos available in Canvas, which delay very often.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is very bad for DSE students, but consider a fact that most of the students get at least B-.

There are two marking schemes, and
Total score = max{Scheme A,Scheme B} + bonus points.
Scheme A: Assignment (22%) + Peer Review (3%) + Midterm Exam (35%) + Final Exam (40%) = Total (100%);
Scheme B: Assignment (22%) + Peer Review (3%) + Midterm Exam (0%) + Final Exam (70%) = Total (95%).

I personally knows the stuff in DSE extremely well, but still can't compensate the gap in between.
I am an Engineering student pre-registered MATH1013 but (I thought) my math is good enough, and somehow I swapped to MATH1023, and I now regret for the fucked up grade.
I get:
Assignment: 456/593 (76.9%)
Midterm Exam: 31/100 (Mean = 55.07, Median = 55.5)
Final Exam: 39/100 (Mean: 65.47, Median = 64)
Total: 47.52 (B-)

The exams are even more difficult than the assignments. (See the attachments.)

There are 6 IMO medalists (international students) in this year, they (probably they) get 100/100 (no typo!!) in the final exam. Almost 80% of other students are from China, that they learn most of the stuff in high school, winning in the beginning. (See the attachments.)

I strongly encourage, take the course if and only if:
1. you are an IMO medalist, or
2. you know HKAL Pure Math well (the style), or
3. you are going to study Math major.
Don't be faked by the M2 level 5 or above requirement.

I later on realize that I can actually stick to MATH1013 and study MATH1023 because their topic are similar in a way that MATH1023 students can handle MATH1013.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very heavy compared with other year 1 courses.

There is an assignment each week (or two weeks for the last 3 assignments), all in total of 10 assignments and the last one is optional, on average each consists of 5 problems selected from the lecture note in Part 1 (no marks but have penalty for not doing them) and 5 problems created by Professor Frederick in Part 2. The problems in Part 2 are very difficult that might be time consuming. (See the attachments.) I personally have no totally completed assignment.

attachments.name: Lecture 12 - Rigorous Definition of Function Limits, Continuity 2
Final Exam Paper (Part 2 only for compressed)

reviews.author: Jonathan:-)
reviews.title: A good math course with really responsible&nice instructor
reviews.comment_content:
We use the lecture notes written by Prof. Yan

Week#  Topic
1           limit of sequences, squeeze theorem
2           rigorous definition of sequential limits
3           monotone sequences, Cauchy sequences
4           infinity, limit of functions
5           rigorous definition of function limits
6           rigorous definition of function limits, continuity
7           continuity

8           derivatives, differentiability
9           chain rule, implicit differentiation
10         monotonicity, first derivative test
11         mean value theorem, l'Hospital's rule
12         Taylor series, higher-order Taylor approximation
13         higher derivative test, convexity and concavity

Overall the content is well organized, from one's intuition to rigorous definition, which can provide you with a solid calculus background.

One flaw is that there are quite a few mistakes in the notes which may affect your understanding of the concept. If you have any question concerning the notes, just ask the professor.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Frederick indeed devoted himself into teaching. He prepared each lectures very well and provided us with enough exercises.

Apart from that, he is also a fun and interesting person.

And if you have any questions, don't hesitate to ask,he is very nice and willing to answer your questions, even some really stupid ones.

Overall his English accent is quite good. May make some mistakes occasionally(i.e, found), but it doesn't cause any difficulties to the listener.

From my perspective, one tiny problem is that, his teaching is somewhat slow and what was taught in the lecture is somewhat easy(unlike the homework problem and the exams which are somewhat hard). And sometimes may be a little bit unclear.(Overall is fine.)

All in all, a good instructor indeed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mostly good, A range is quite large.

To score a little bit higher than mean can make you an A-. And there are almost no C or D range(less than 15%).

There are 2 grading scheme:
A
Homework 22%+ Peer review 3%+ Midterm 35%+ Final 40%
OR
B
Homework 22%+ Peer review 3%+ Midterm 0%+ Final 70%

You can still improve your letter grade even you screw up very badly in midterm.

However, the A+ cut-off is sky high. You have to work very hard indeed.

The GRADING overall is WAY BETTER than before.
reviews.comment_workload:
As an honor math course, the workload is indeed somewhat heavy.

You need to spend some time to understand the concept.

And there will be weekly assignments, which may be somewhat difficult.

reviews.author: LukaModric
reviews.comment_content:
1.1 Limit of Sequence
1.2 Rigorous Definition of Sequence Limit
1.3 Criterion for convergence
1.4 Infinity
1.5 Limit of Function
1.6 Rigorous Definition of Function Limit
1.7 Continuity
2.1 Linear Approximation
2.2 Property of Derivative
2.3 Application of Linear Approximation
2.4 Mean Value Theorem
2.5 High Order Approxiamtion
2.6 Application of High Order Approximation
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite clear.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 22%
Peer Review 3%
Midterm 35%
Final 40%
Total 100%

OR

Homework 22%
Peer Review 3%
Midterm 0%
Final 70%
Total 95%
reviews.comment_workload:
Compulsory: Problem Set #1-9 + Peer review
(You have to review 2 students' work for each problem set) (Each problem set has part 1 for peer review and part 2 graded by instructor and TAs)

Bonus: Problem Set X
Bonus: 1 Question in Canvas discussion (First five students can get bonus points)

reviews.author: Jason Ieong
reviews.comment_content: Stress on the proof and logic flow of theory regarding limit of sequence and function, and calculus, including stuff such as rigorous definition of limit, convergence, Cauchy sequence, continuity, derivative, linear approximation, mean value theorem, central limit theorem, etc. the basic theory is taught during lecture and some application and prove of theory extended from the basic ones may be taught on tutor or as our homework.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is not bad but i still found it hard to apply what they taught into application of the homework and test.
reviews.comment_grading:
It may be easy to get a good grade if you know what you are doing, and I believe that over 90% could above B and 40% get an a. Also, there are two schemes that one counts midterm and the other doesn't, while the scheme that doesn't count have and the maximum mark of 95%, so people with poor performance in the first midterm may have a chance to improve at the final.However, I am pretty sure that it is easier to get a better grade in math 1013. For your reference here's a quote from an announcement regarding the midterm:
"Total = 100
Highest = 100
Mean = 55.07
Median = 55.5
I have also posted a table showing the scores of all students anonymously.
Note that your letter grade will also take into account of homework, final exam and bonus credits. Just give a rough idea: if the letter grade were hypothetically based on this midterm alone, then you may expect A+ would be 88 or above, the A-/B+ cutoff would be ~63, and B-/C+ cutoff would be around 29~31.
Keep in mind that Scheme B of the grading policy gives you great opportunity to improve your letter grade."
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly homework and they are HARD
Takes me like two to three days to finish it per week.

reviews.author: Tangran
reviews.title: Just so so
reviews.comment_content: The notes are not very hard,  so the content is not very challenging. But some of the content is lost, compared with that in mainland such as the upper and lower limit, or Stolz theorem, which is very regettable.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching skills are just so so, but I heard that it will be better when he teaches 4023 or others.
reviews.comment_grading: The grades he gave is very good, and many of us got better grades than expected.
reviews.comment_workload: In the first year in hkust, the workload of 1023 is not very hard.

reviews.author: holymama
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are quite challenging. Yet, some MO (Mathematical Olympiad) stuff is required, like AMGM inequality.
Topics:
inequalities
functions and their graphs
limit and continuity,
extreme value theorem
intermediate value theorem
derivatives and differentiation rules,
mean value theorem,
l'HÃ´pital's rule,
Taylor expansion, and applications of derivatives.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The most humorous and elegant instructor ever.
Yet, the tutor is just bullshxt. I don't really know what he was doing because his presentation skills was extremely poor. I would like to spend more time on those tutorial problems with my friends or the tutor in maths support center rather than attending the tutorial classes held by that guy. (Chan Yan Long)
reviews.comment_grading:
As mentioned by prof A0, 70% students will be above B range,

Anyway, I got a quite nice grade (B+). Due to my useless brain, I can't perform really well in my maths course, tho I would like to take chemistry as my major.
reviews.comment_workload:
Better than Min Yan, as some year 2 Maths students told me that they need to hand in over 50 questions per week, but we only have to hand in 10 of them.

But well... The questions set by Prof. Fong was really really hard.  You somehow need to spend lots of time on it.

reviews.author: LOL lol
reviews.title: Prof. YAN is sooooo cute!
reviews.comment_content: Basic calculus things, kind of in-depth.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. YAN really has his own thoughts on those topics involved in this course and he can explain everything clearly and very logically. Although his teaching is almost totally the same as his notes (written by himself and explain everything in details), it is worthwhile to go to his classes!

Well, he stop for a break for 5 min after every 15 min... Interesting, right? At that time you can feel free to ask him any questions and digest what you've just learned. He is always patient in asking students' questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not bad, both midterm and final are in the form of about only 10 long questions. And they are both open-notes exams which means you can bring almost everything with you
Prof. YAN attaches a lot of importance on how you solve the problem, so the steps are the most important. And as long as your methods make sense, he will give you the marks.
Midterm exam: 30%
Final exam: 50%
Homework: 20%
A+ is above 95/100 overall.
A is above 90/100 overall.
In fact, if you work out all the questions in the exams, getting an A will be pretty easy since prof. YAN is quite generous on giving marks.
You do not need to worry about the homework. Few marks will be deducted as long as you hand in them every time.
reviews.comment_workload: Kind of heavy, since you have to hand in a set of questions written by hand every week. And it cost a lot of time and effort to do this, especially after midterm. But they deserve that much time and effort because they are really helpful in exams!

reviews.author: hayden tse
reviews.title: Difficult but you can get B range if you work hard(2 to 3hours per day on average)
reviews.comment_content:
Prof Yan spent 2 months to talk about limit, from the rough meaning of limit, different tricks to solve limit, to the rigorous defination of limit(Îµ-Î´ definition). All of them were taguht by rigorous prove and logic.
Afterwards, prof Yan only spent 1 month to teach differentiation, including rigorous defination of differentiation(linear approximation), mean value theorem, l'HÃ´pital's rule, Taylor expansion.
The main difference between 1023 and 1013 is that 1023 require you to understand all the rigorous prove but 1013 just give you the solution.
I think the content is too much and we don't have enough time to digest all of them before exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both lecture and tutorial are useful, don't skip it.
Both Prof Yan and Li Xilin can explain the concept clearly by only a few words, you can follow him easily, given that you can catchup the last lesson and well prepered.
LI Xilin can speak English without accent though he came from Minland. Moveover, his tutorial worksheets are great tool for your practise.
reviews.comment_grading:
20%HW
30%midterm
50%final
Prof Yan posted all the scores on the door of his office, see attachments. I think the grading is reasonable.
reviews.comment_workload:
8 homework
Most questions are testing the fundamental concept in this course but don't expect they will be easy. Workload is extremely hearvy(see attachments), this is why I said you should spend 2 to 3 hours per day on this course, unless you are talented in math.

1 midterm and1final
You will have 3 hours to solve 5 questions, 4 of them are extremely difficult, far more difficult than any question in Dse math, m1 or m2.

reviews.author: slw
reviews.comment_content:
Some basic theorems and properties of limit. (i.e.  limit of sequence, properties of limit, monotone sequence, Cauchy criterion, infinity, limit of function, continuous function, intermediate value theorem, invertible continuous function)
Some basic theorems and properties of differentiation. (i.e.linear approximation, derivative, property of derivative, monotone function, extrema, means value theorem, high order approximation, high order derivative, Taylor expansion.)
reviews.comment_teaching: Min Yan teaches quite well. His english pronunciation is clear. He tries to derive everything step by step by using pens and a pice of paper. Obviously, he did prepare before the lessons. But sometimes it is sleep inducing. We had lots of breaks during the lessons which according to min yan is for you to digest what he had taught and ask him questions. But I think the breaks are not necessary. Min Yan is also willing to answer any questions you raised.
reviews.comment_grading:
20%HW, 30% midterm, 50% final
Grading is fair. I believe it is quite hard for you to fail in this course but at the same time it is also hard to get really good grade. Just try your best to follow is okay.
reviews.comment_workload: No attendance is required. You can skip all the lessons. Weekly assignment is given in the notes. It is quite time consuming to do the assignments but it is a good practise for your final and midterm. Both final and midterm are open notes, you do not need to memorise the notes. If your concept is correct, the midterm and final should not be really hard to do.

reviews.author: huxing
reviews.title: Great course, highly recommended
reviews.comment_content: Covering limits and differentiation. Crucial to any kind of further learning in mathematics. The course is very well structured, requiring no previous knowledge of Calculus; however, proficiency in some high school-level mathematical operations is highly conducive.
reviews.comment_teaching: Organized, well-reasoned, engaging, supplemented with loads of examples. (Far) better than average pronunciation.

(20% Homework, 30% Midterm, 50% Final)
Fair. As long as you finish homework and be well-prepared for exams, getting an A or above should be easy.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly homework, each taking 1~2 hours, mostly on the low side. On average, 2 hours weekly workload.

reviews.comment_grading:

And the mean is high enough.
reviews.comment_workload: Every week have problem sets from the text book and it really takes time and sometime there is no answer and we have to search for answers through some website that Professor will tell you during the lecture.

reviews.author: Jerome
reviews.title: Sorry, I would modify it after finishing this course!
reviews.comment_content: Good to understand! Only if you take enough time will you find you get better insight into calculus!
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher stresses much importance on the demonstration because he believes idea is more important than calculating!
reviews.comment_grading: Since the A range is wider so it might seem easier to get a A. But the density of mainland students is also large. Therefore, getting a A is actually challenging!

reviews.comment_content:
Very useful for math & phys student.
If you do like the course style you can still take 1014 in the next semester as 1024 will be taught by the same person as 1023.
reviews.comment_teaching:
If you do not like the joke, the course is the like hell.
But if you do understand what the hell he is talking about, then this is the right course for you xD.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade is pretty good, if you have learned it before.
around 10 A+ for
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy at all.
very little assignment weekly.
One mid term and one final.

reviews.title: A good math course
reviews.comment_content:
Less than Math 1013, but more adequate.
Very interesting, professor is funny and often talk about other math knowledge to us.
Tutorial is useful and more difficult than lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching: HU did not use ppt in class. He like writing something on the white board and do not have notes. So we need take note by ourselves.

reviews.author: Xiaofeng Xu
reviews.comment_content:
VERY INTERESTING. The prof is quite funny and talk a lot about what he thinks mathematics is. quite a lot to learn from this course as well as the teacher.
the exams are fine. personally i find the tutorial notes are more difficult than the exam questions.
the tutorial teacher is quite good as well, he explains things patiently and explicitly.
only up to differentiation is covered in this course without any integration.
reviews.comment_teaching: interesting and inspiring
reviews.comment_grading: quite good, competitive class
reviews.comment_workload: not much homework to do but better do some exercises yourself

reviews.author: Sophia_Li
reviews.comment_content: this course contains limit of  function as well as sequence, Rolle's law, mean value theory, L'Hospital's role, property of function, not as abundant as i expected.
reviews.comment_teaching: quite clear, and the professor himself is very nice. you are sure to understand the question that he has taught. but sometimes he likes to speak Chinese during class.
reviews.comment_grading: very well, a large number of people in A range. But it's hard to get an A+
reviews.comment_workload: quite small. only one midterm, final and homework eyery week. Homework are always questions from the text book, which won't take much time.

reviews.author: harrier
reviews.title: Challenging course
reviews.comment_content: This course is basically equal to 1013, but with many more vigorous delta-epsilon prove of differentation. This will be somehow challenging, but once you practice well you will be fine.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof HU is passionate on the vigorous proof part, but somehow lose interest of the regular 1013 differentation part......

TA in the course is very nice and helpful, he explain the concept clear, basically he will answer every question you asked...
reviews.comment_grading:
Because this is a honor course, the mean is very high. only above overall ~91/2% can get A range.

But if you fail midterm, you can never get even an B.

Midterm is about vigorous proof, while final is easy this semester...
reviews.comment_workload: Although the assignment only take 5% of overall and not challenging, with low workload...if you want to have a good grade, you must self-practice and summerize the vigorous proof, which is quite a workload

reviews.author: E
reviews.title: Great!
reviews.comment_content: Before the midterm, the course covers the rigorous definition of limits (That is how to prove for example that the limit as x approaches a of x^2 = a^2 using well defined mathematical formulations and being rigorous while doing so). This part emphasized proofs and professor Hu Proved everything he wrote, and I mean everything. You won't be expected to repeat his proofs in the exam but you are expected to understand them since you can use a similar way to prove other questions he might ask. Also, he covers all the differentiation rules and again proofs the product rule, quotient rule, etc. After the midterm, he focused on on the applications such as optimization problems, sketching graphs, intermediate value theorem, mean value theorem, L'hospital rule, local and global minima and maxima, concavity, etc. Overall, the course has a really rewarding content and I definitely recommend taking it if 1) you don't care about the grade that much and 2) if you are going to major in maths. The course has improved my mathematical maturity so much and made me think of most stuff in terms of their proofs and definitions, definitely a well constructed calculus course and is almost the same difficulty (if not harder) than other calculus courses in other US universities such as MIT and Caltech, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Hu, for me is one of the best mathematics professors that ever thaught me in my life. He has many famous sentences such as: "You don't know the definition, you get a big 0" and "Your intuition tells you that this limit is 0? well my intuition tells me that YOU get a 0" and finally "Analysis is a hard subject, every year at least 3 people commit suicide in MIT because of analysis:". Professor Hu teaching is extremely funny and laid down and you can sense he enjoys what he does, he focuses on two things: LOGIC and DEFINITION, if you lack one in your answer then you're getting a big 0. For example, the limit as x approaches infinity of (1/(x+4)) = 0 since the denominator grows to infinity and 1 divided by a very big number is 0. if you write this in the exam you get a 0. To get the mark, you can either 1) proof that the limit of 1/x+4 is indeed 0 by the DEFINITION or use logic and algebraic manipulation to write 1/x+4 as (1/x)/(1+4/x). since we know limit as x approaches infinity of 1/x = limit of 4/x  = 0 and by the continuity of the polynomials, the limit is 0/(1+0) = 0/1 = 0 therefore we conclude the limit is 0. See how many steps we needed to show the limit of such an easy limit is 0? you have to follow similar arguments in ALL your answers or else, a big 0.

A final word about the TA (Xilin Li), this is arguably one of the best TAs in the maths department, the guy is very nice, he explains things thoroughly and you can meet him after class and he would even explain FULL lessons to you after class if you need it, he is always at the maths support center most of the time and I honestly wouldn't have gotten my A- without this guy. Seriously a life saver.

Also, for the lecture notes, review the attachments below, study from these notes since they are much harder and rigorous than the Stewart calculus book. everyone studies from it.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is shit, no way to put it except this way. The students who take this course are all really mathematically mature and well, really really good in maths. When I went to professor Hu at the beginning of the year, I asked him if I should take the course since I am an international student and most students who take it are from mainland (if not all of them) and they are known to be the best in maths. He told me you should take it butt you might get a C or C+ even if you're good because these guys are really good, I ended up in the end getting an A- (Even though I regard myself to be exceptional in mathematics and I ranked in the top 1.8 percentile in the maths exam in my country) and I studied a lot! So if this tells you something, its that the course is full of good people, and in the end, around 40% got A- or higher and I barely hit the A- level. So be very careful if you need to maintain a certain gpa for your scholarship, I know you might really think you are very good in maths, but so did I and you're going to have to work your ass off just to get an A.

45% midterm, 5% H.W, and 50% finals.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is ridiculous, seriously. I remember that I studied this subject about 4 hours a day, solving problems, and understanding the definition. You have to put loads of effort for this course so don't take too many courses with it like I did.

reviews.author: grqm
reviews.comment_content:
A course in differential calculus.

First half of the course: limits of sequences; functional limits (Îµ-Î´ definition), difficult but very intereseting
It would be a good idea to pick and read an analysis book

Second half: applications like the L'hopital rules, optimisation, curve sketching. There was nothing new and hard so many got full marks in the final exam.

But Taylor series and Leibniz rule were left out this year.
But the final exam tested Newton's method which is not in his syllabus
reviews.comment_teaching: You will probably like him If you are talented enough. Otherwise no.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 5%
Midterm 40%
Final 55%

Studied 3 days for the midterm and 2 days for the final.
Overall Score 90% => A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Light, as the homework counts only 5% towards the grade.
A good way to study is: work out as many problems as possible.

reviews.author: SharonMiao
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers limits and differentiation.
Before mid-term: proving limits using rigorous definitions
After mid-term: Applications of differentiation and L'hospitals Rule

Prof. Hu puts more emphasis on understanding definitions and less on lmastering algebraic techniques He didn't cover Leibniz's rule and Taylor polynomial, also didn't ask questions that requires (maybe unnatural) construction of functions to prove things.

I think 1023 is tough but manageable. Anyone with reasonable math sense could handle this class. I'd recommend this course to students who like to challenge themselves and share a love for math. Even if you only get a 5 in DSE math/ M2, I guarantee that you can still perform well in this course if you work hard.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very nice! Clearly he teaches with heart and brain. I don't know how to describe how well he taught. But I can assure you that his teaching could elevate your understanding in calculus to a whole new level.

What he focused on is DEFINITIONS! He said it many times in the lesson, 'MATHEMATICS IS ABOUT DEFINITIONS!!!!!' So instead of testing a hell ton of algebraic techniques he rather tested on how well you reason your steps. He once said it class while pointing his finger to a student, 'Your intuition tells the limit is 0, you get a 0!' I got a mark deduction because of skipping a tiny step when proving limits -.-!

But his approach of marking really forced students to beware of the importance of definitions, which makes 1023 much more rewarding (in terms of content only) than 1013. 1023 helps students adapting uni math. Students will eventually realize how dangerous it will be to do math without understanding definitions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 5%.; Midterm Exams: 40%.; Final Exam: 55%

The competition is fierce. Around 50% of students got more than 85 this year.

The grading is unfortunately bad :'(!Because Prof. Hu will only give A to a certain percentage students, if you get between 80 - 90, you'll probably get a B+. But what makes me feel bad is, this year's 1013 has a better grading than 1023 -.-!
reviews.comment_workload:
Prof. Hu didn't give out a lot of homework this year. He took homework problems from Stewart calculus weekly starting right after the mid-term. And homework only accounts for 5% towards the final grade.

So he only thing to do in order to perform well in this course is - studying!

reviews.author: navI
reviews.comment_content: MATH 1023 is a more in depth version of MATH 1013. Their content is similar but fundamentally different. Both courses teaches only limit and differentiation, but 1023's is a more rigorous version and you are required to give a lot of reasoning. It surely require a strong background of mathematics in order to follow the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Personally, Prof. Yan is my favorite professor. He like derive the different theorem with a pen and paper. All the steps he had done was well explained and his every derivation was based on the immediate sense he have.
Besides, I can sense that Prof. Yan is a respectable person.
reviews.comment_grading: His grading is not tight at all (but I don't have the statistics). Somebody told me if you are in the top 5% of the class, you will be able to have an A+ and the mean of the class is about B or B+. I am surely not a outstanding one since I only able to have a B+ with about 70% in the overall score.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload of this course was somewhat heavy. You are sometimes required to do a great number of questions in a week. Some of them are extremely difficult (not all of them are marked though). But I totally agree this is a kind of training.

reviews.author: Kelvin
reviews.comment_content: A much more rigorous and a difficult course compared to math1013. The topics are actually same with math1013 but there are many proofs for you to learn thoughout the course. However, you will still get stuck with your weekly hw even you understand the proofs of the textbook. In my opinion, don't take this course if your DSE math core or m2 got lower than 5*. If you wish to take it, you will have to spend twice more time in this course than usual courses. And if you think you are really good at math in high school, you will probably change your mind after taking this course. Actually, I think this course is even more difficult than some math courses start with 2, so please think in-depth before you take this course. Its still worth to try if you really want to test yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor has a solid foundation at calculus but his teaching is not good. It takes some time to understand his English.
reviews.comment_grading: Quite bad. As a honor course, the grading should be much more better than math1013 as students are all good at math basically. Indeed, physics honor course (phys1312) has a better grade. However, the mean grade of this course is around B. (Not absolutely sure since it's heard from others)
reviews.comment_workload: The weekly hw are very difficult. Its better to know someone in class and discuss when you have difficulty. Typically it will spend 2-3 days to finish the weekly hw, and you have to spend time to understand the materials in textbook, so the workload is really heavy.

reviews.author: O
reviews.title: Warning! Don't try this course if you are not best students
reviews.comment_content:
Rigorous proof and definitions of differentiation and some integration.
Really advise you to have at least 5* in M2 and even 5** in Maths to have this course.
The first week is only the introdctory of the course and if you still dont know what he say, then go to choose 1013. Because the latter one will be more difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I was taught by Wu Jishan and he was bad teacher in my opinion.
I saw they changed the teacher in 2014 fall and the teacher now taught 1023 I think is much more better.
Wu Jishan will answer your questions but he will answer in a way that he was not patient and underlooked you. And he did not teach in details so I nearly skipped all the classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you got 4t something in the course, for whole semester, you will got C or above.
It is very hard to get a fail in Wu Jishan scale maybe only 1 or 2. Other will get a D.
But as this course is in the lowest Math level and it is a pre requisite course for other maths course, please ensure yourself not having a F with you
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy in Wu Jishan teaching.
Every time you will have maybe 10 to 15 problems in the book but they are extremely difficult. The book sample questions are so basic and different in levels compare to the questions he chose. Hope things got better in the new lecturer.
